"Singles are boring." Gregory looked at Evelyn. "Doubles? You and your wife versus Evelyn and me."

Alexander’s gaze turned icy. "Are you underestimating me, Doctor?"

Gregory smirked. "Who exactly are you doubting—Evelyn or me?"
###Chapter 289: The Silent Rivalry Between Men

Evelyn Carter abruptly looked up at Gregory Wilson.

She truly knew nothing about billiards.

Could he really take on two opponents alone?

Alexander Hamilton's gaze swept over Gregory like a stalking panther assessing its rival.

Gregory met his stare unflinchingly, posture relaxed.

"Annabelle!" Yvonne Young suddenly cried out, catching the swaying Annabelle Taylor.

Annabelle's face had gone deathly pale as she slumped against Yvonne, her voice barely audible. "I'm...fine..."

Gregory glanced at her pallid complexion. "Mr. Hamilton should take his fiancée to the hospital first."

Alexander frowned deeply. "What's really going on?"

Annabelle's lashes fluttered, tears glistening. "It's...nothing...the game...can continue..."

She braced herself against the pool table, forcing herself upright. "Dr. Carter...would you play one round with me?"

Evelyn exchanged a glance with Gregory.

Annabelle's condition didn't seem feigned.

"Another time," Evelyn said. "I have matters to attend to."

"Don't go!" Annabelle suddenly lunged forward, grabbing Evelyn's wrist. "Please...just one game..."

Vivian Dempsey immediately stepped between them. "Let go! If you want to play the victim, go to your fiancé!"

Annabelle gave a bitter smile. "...Fiancé?"

"Annabelle!" Yvonne cut in indignantly. "Alex will marry you eventually!"

She emphasized the last words deliberately, her gaze piercing Evelyn.

Annabelle's face turned even paler. "Yvonne, stop."

"Hmph!" Yvonne stormed off. "Ungrateful!"

The moment Yvonne turned away, both Annabelle and Vincent Wilson exhaled in relief.

"Hey!" Yvonne suddenly spun back. "Some people shouldn't eye others while already taken!"

Vincent frantically waved his hands at her, as if begging on his knees.

Vivian took a deep breath. "The air clears when certain people leave. Vincent, what were you thinking back then?"

Vincent chuckled awkwardly. "Youthful ignorance. Weren't you also—"

"Ahem!" Evelyn coughed pointedly.

Vincent immediately fell silent.

Gregory spoke up smoothly. "Are you sure you don't need medical attention, Miss Taylor?"

Annabelle didn't answer, only fixing Evelyn with pleading eyes. "I want...to play one game with Dr. Carter..."
###Chapter 290: A Familiar Stance

Gregory Wilson handed her the cue. "What do you think, Dr. Carter?"

Evelyn Carter ran her fingers along the smooth surface of the cue. "I'm still a beginner," she said softly. "And Miss Taylor isn't feeling well. This seems fair."

"Want to give it a try?"

She lifted her gaze to meet his. "What about you?"

"I'll play if you do."

Vincent Wilson had already set up the table with quick efficiency. Vivian Dempsey gave Evelyn's shoulder a light pat. "I need to take a call."

"Okay."

As Alexander Hamilton shrugged off his suit jacket, Annabelle Taylor instinctively reached for it. He sidestepped her and called out, "Vincent."

Vincent jogged over to take the jacket, flashing Annabelle an easy smile. "Focus on the game, Annabelle. I'll handle the small stuff."

Her smile tightened. "Alright."

Once the game began, Alexander dominated effortlessly. The cue became an extension of his will, sending one colored ball after another into the pockets.

Only the eight-ball remained.

Straightening up, Alexander smirked. "Leaving Dr. Wilson a chance."

Gregory studied the flawless trajectory and chuckled, shaking his head. "The outcome's already decided."

"How about settling the wager?"

"It's just for fun."

As Gregory bent to take his shot, Annabelle suddenly interrupted. "Wait!"

Alexander's expression darkened. "What now?"

"It's... my turn," she said, her voice trembling slightly.

Gregory arched a brow and offered her the cue. "Be my guest."

The way Annabelle positioned herself made Evelyn freeze. The lowered torso, the steady bridge hand, even the precise angle of her grip—it mirrored Alexander's technique exactly.

Gregory's lips curved knowingly. "Mr. Hamilton taught you well."

Alexander's face turned stormy. "That was a long time ago."

Evelyn kept her eyes downcast.

"Young love is the purest," Gregory mused. "That kind of heart-fluttering feeling... it might only happen once in a lifetime."

Alexander's voice was icy. "Youthful ignorance leads to poor choices."
###Chapter 291: The Most Heartfelt Love of a Lifetime

"Where is the line between right and wrong? Is it achieving success or having a perfect family? No one can judge whether a choice was right or wrong until the very end."

Alexander Hamilton wore a faint smile. "Dr. Wilson, you speak as if you've lived through it yourself. Did you also have someone who made your heart race in your youth?"

"Of course."

A trace of mockery crept into Alexander's smile. "Then doesn't your earlier 'philosophy on youth' contradict itself? At our age, everyone has a past. Since we're all starting from the same place, why play favorites?"

Gregory Wilson crossed his arms, his gaze steady. "I do have a past. But how do you know the person from my past isn't the same as the one in my present?"

Alexander's expression darkened instantly. He turned sharply toward Evelyn. "You knew each other before?!"

"Did you forget we're both doctors?"

"Vincent said you were abroad all this time. And Evelyn—" His voice tightened. "She never studied overseas."

"Education isn't imprisonment. Visiting family during holidays, academic exchanges, occasional trips back—what's so strange about that?"

Alexander's eyes grew colder. "You decided she was the one after just a few meetings? Without even knowing her background? Isn't that reckless?"

"We're different, Alexander. You had a childhood sweetheart. I had to believe in love at first sight."

Alexander scoffed. "That's not a very convincing story, Dr. Wilson. Love at first sight? Such things are rare."

Gregory met his gaze, his voice soft but firm. "Youth knows neither love nor hate—yet it's when the heart beats the hardest."

"Ah—!"

Annabelle's startled cry finally broke the tension between them.

The billiards table had become a battlefield.

What was once a clear path to victory had turned into an expertly crafted snooker. The eight-ball was completely blocked by the colored balls, ruining what should have been an easy win.

Already frustrated, Alexander's anger flared. "Did you do this on purpose?"

Annabelle's eyes reddened. "I—"

"I should've let Yvonne take you with her earlier."

"I just wanted to give you two more time together!" Annabelle cried, her voice trembling. "She won't even talk to you now. I was just... trying to help..."

Alexander froze, his frown deepening. "Annabelle, you destroyed the trust between us yourself. I heard every word Yvonne said earlier."

"That was years ago! I've changed now! My parents talked to me after they came back..." She took a shaky breath. "They went to see Dr. Carter..."

Alexander stiffened. "Why would they go to her?!"

"Don't panic," Annabelle said, her voice unsteady. "What if I told you they went to bring you two back together? Would you believe me?"

Alexander laughed coldly. "Do you think I would?"

"I know you don't. But it's the truth. They discussed it for a long time. I owe you, but you don’t care about my family’s business... They wanted to make it up to you."

Alexander's gaze turned sharp as a blade. "Compensation? Or begging me not to kick you out?"

"...Both."

"So hiring that actress to cause a scene at my company—that was your parents' idea too?"
###Chapter 292: Do You Still Want to Stop Me, Alexander?

Annabelle's head drooped lower.

"It was my own foolishness. My parents already gave me a stern lecture." Her voice was barely audible. "I know your heart belongs to Dr. Carter now. My parents said they've watched you grow up and understand your temperament. After causing you such a huge loss, you'd never swallow this injustice."

She paused, stealing a glance at Alexander Hamilton.

"Perhaps... I should find a way to make you happy."

The private room fell silent.

Gregory Wilson let out a soft chuckle. "That's quite an interesting proposition, Miss Taylor."

Annabelle bit her lip. "I know you all think I'm being hypocritical. But I mean it. If Alexander can reconcile with Dr. Carter, I'll feel at peace."

Her eyes reddened. "My parents are getting older, and I'm their only daughter. Everyone in our circle knows I can't have children..."

Gregory sighed. "Parents' hearts ache for their children."

"I know my sins are grave." Annabelle's nails dug into her palms. "Grandma Hamilton haunts my dreams every night, cursing me for ruining Alexander. All I want now is to atone..."

Evelyn Carter suddenly laughed.

"You don't believe me, Dr. Carter?"

"What do you think?" Evelyn arched a brow.

Annabelle took a deep breath. "I'll prove it to you. From now on, Alexander and I will be strangers. If it displeases you, we won't even need to be friends."

"Unnecessary." Evelyn's tone was flat. "I won't be around to see it."

"What do you mean?"

"I'm going abroad." Evelyn's gaze swept over Alexander's tensed jawline. "At least three years, possibly longer."

Alexander's head snapped up. "Where?"

"Undecided."

"When?"

"Waiting for the hospital's arrangements."

Alexander's knuckles turned white. "Are the formalities completed?"

Evelyn's lips curved. "What's the matter, Alexander? Still trying to stop me?"

The air froze.

Annabelle's eyes widened in shock.

Gregory pensively stroked his teacup.

Alexander's Adam's apple bobbed violently, but no words came out.
###Chapter 293: Annabelle's Secret

The sharp crack of colliding billiard balls ceased abruptly.

Gregory Wilson straightened up after his final masterful shot, the colored balls dropping neatly into the pockets. A confident smirk played on his lips. "Good game."

Vivian Dempsey burst in, phone still pressed to her ear. "What? It's over already?"

"If Miss Taylor hadn't gone easy on me," Gregory said, leisurely polishing his cue, "you'd still be waiting in the parking lot."

"Whatever." Vivian hung up, waving her phone excitedly. "Perfect timing! I just got great news. Let's go—my treat to celebrate!"

Annabelle leaned heavily against the pool table, her face deathly pale. "You go ahead... I'm not feeling well..."

Vivian snorted. "Who said I was inviting you? This is for Evelyn and Dr. Wilson."

Annabelle's fingers dug into her palms as she swayed unsteadily. Her lips parted, but no sound emerged.

"Hey," Vivian frowned, eyeing her suspiciously. "You're not about to pull some fake injury stunt, are you? Just so we're clear—I haven't laid a finger on you."

Annabelle's pupils suddenly dilated. Her knees buckled—

Thud.

The sickening impact silenced the room. Annabelle collapsed face-first onto the floor, blood rapidly pooling beneath her.

Alexander Hamilton shot to his feet, his gaze darting between Evelyn and Annabelle's motionless form.

"Let's go!"
Vivian grabbed Evelyn's wrist, practically dragging her toward the exit. As the glass door swung shut, Evelyn caught Alexander's enraged roar and Vincent Wilson's panicked shouts.

The car ride was suffocatingly quiet.

Through the rearview mirror, Gregory watched Vivian nervously twisting her fingers while Evelyn stared blankly out the window, her profile betraying no emotion.

"Worried about her?" Gregory finally broke the silence.

"Who'd worry about that scheming witch?" Vivian bristled like a startled cat. "It's just... the way she fell looked pretty bad..."

At a red light, Gregory turned to face them. "Facial impact likely caused fractures. And judging by her posture during the fall, she was already unconscious."

Vivian peeked at Evelyn's expression and seized her hand. "She deserved it! Remember when you miscarried, Evelyn? The bathroom was covered in blood—I still get chills thinking about it..."

"Vivian." Evelyn's quiet rebuke held steel.

"Well it's true!" Vivian's eyes reddened. "You were skin and bones afterward, and even now your periods leave you sweating in pain..."

Gregory deftly changed the subject. "Miss Taylor's condition seemed abnormal. Her symptoms before collapsing suggest chronic anemia causing sudden syncope."

The car jolted over a speed bump.

As city lights blurred past the window, Evelyn recalled Annabelle's bloodless lips earlier—and the faint needle marks barely concealed beneath her sleeves.
###Chapter 294: Shouldn't Good Looks and Stamina At Least Serve a Purpose?

Vivian Dempsey suddenly slapped her thigh. "Could it be complications from that abortion procedure?"

The traffic light turned green.

Gregory Wilson pressed the accelerator lightly, brows furrowed. "Uncertain."

Evelyn Carter shook her head. "Dr. Porter is highly experienced. The surgery shouldn't be the issue."

"If the surgery wasn't the problem, maybe her recovery was poor?" Vivian leaned closer. "Evelyn, wouldn't a late-term abortion require postpartum care like a mini-confinement? Could she have developed complications?"

Evelyn replied seriously, "So-called 'confinement illnesses' are essentially the irreversible physical toll of childbirth. Ancient societies blamed 'poor postpartum care' to encourage more births."

"No wonder. Annabelle's family is wealthy—her postnatal care should've been impeccable." Vivian propped her chin on her hand. "Then why does she look so sickly?"

Gregory interjected quietly, "Her condition might be unrelated to the surgery."

"Then what's the cause?"

"She was... quite unrestrained abroad."

The implication was clear.

Vivian scoffed. "Alexander Hamilton's love runs deep, huh? How could he not know Annabelle was so wild overseas?"

"Didn't he choose to marry Evelyn and give up on Annabelle?"

Vivian smirked. "And yet he still divorced to go back and clean up her mess."

Gregory sighed. "As Yvonne said, none of us understand what Annabelle means to Alexander."

Vivian shot a glance at Evelyn.

"What is it?" Evelyn asked.

Vivian linked arms with her. "Nothing. Just some good news."

"What good news?"

"Natalie Stapleton just called. Simon refuses to divorce."

Evelyn recalled Alexander's interrupted words earlier. "What exactly happened?"

Vivian animatedly explained, "Simon and his mother had a falling out. He's desperate to divorce and climb the social ladder, but his mother wants to extort more from the Zhao family—thinks her son shouldn't have been a gigolo for nothing."

Evelyn frowned. "A gigolo? If Natalie wanted a gigolo, shouldn't she at least get someone with looks or stamina? What does Simon even have?"

"That mother-son pair operates on a different wavelength. Greedier than the next."

"What happened then?"

Vivian grinned triumphantly. "Your hospital director kicked them out. Natalie said her father's already hired a lawyer to file for divorce. Even if it takes a decade, the Stapletons won't get a single cent!"

Evelyn exhaled in relief. "It won't take that long. Simon's shrewder than his mother—he knows what's at stake."

"Hah! Of course. Alexander did alright this time. That Lora girl looks so... influencer-ish. But men seem to eat that up. Their taste is baffling. Add the 'Oceanic Group heiress' title, and Simon was bound to take the bait."

Gregory remarked dryly, "Most free lunches are poisoned."

"Poisoned or not, a social-climbing leech like Simon would sprint onto any escalator he sees."

"True." Gregory nodded. "Then we'll just wait for his inevitable fall."
###Chapter 295: On the Eve of Departure

Though born with a silver spoon in her mouth, Vivian Dempsey had an insatiable love for street food.

She led the group into a humble little Spicy Hot Pot shop.

"Hiss—" Vivian gasped from the heat but kept shoving meatballs into her mouth. "I've been eating here for three years. Authentic as it gets!"

Evelyn Carter opted for a mild broth, leisurely picking at the vegetables.

Gregory Wilson stared at the greasy tabletop, his frown deep enough to crush flies. "You brought her to a place like this?"

"Why not?" Vivian slapped the table. "Evelyn used to haunt the food stalls behind our campus!"

Evelyn chuckled. "Even the professors frequented the vendors near the med school. Now those classmates are all department heads in major hospitals."

"Exactly!" Vivian stuffed a slice of lotus root into her mouth. "Better than some people putting on airs with their fancy Western meals."

Gregory fell silent for a moment before suddenly waving the owner over. "One mild broth, please."

"Oh? The great Dr. Wilson finally stooping to our level?" Vivian teased with a smirk.

He scoffed. "Only for Evelyn's sake."

At the hospital, the handover proceeded smoothly.

Dr. Porter adjusted her reading glasses as she reviewed the files. "This old bones still have some use. Don’t worry about us."

Olivia Lightfoot clung to Evelyn, crying like a child. "Dr. Carter, don’t forget to send me chocolates!"

Evelyn ruffled her hair, a pang of envy flickering in her chest.

Such simple happiness was beautiful.

Late that night, Emily Anderson called.

"Don’t be sad, sis." Her voice was tender with concern. "I heard about Peter moving to S City."

Evelyn’s grip on the phone tightened.

"You two were perfect together..." Emily grumbled. "Does his company have no one else? Why tear you apart?"

The cold moonlight spilled through the window. Evelyn studied her reflection in the glass and softly murmured, "Yeah."
###Chapter 296: Ordinary People in the Tide of Fate

"Did Auntie Lucy really hint at that?"

"She didn't say it outright, but she was very apologetic, constantly making amends to Mom and Dad. Don't worry though—they're taking it better than expected. They just said some things aren't meant to be."

Evelyn Carter exhaled in relief. "How are Mom and Dad holding up these days?"

"Mom sighs sometimes, but she understands Peter's choice. Dad hasn't been affected at all—he's been glued to the TV watching the Olympics."

"That's good. Since I'm not home, make sure to help them more."

"Got it, sis." Emily Anderson replied obediently. "Oh, by the way, Peter already helped me finalize my college applications. You don’t need to come home this weekend."

"He went to our house?"

"No, probably too awkward. He had me come over to his place to fill everything out."

"Still going for Hudson Tech? What major?"

"Materials Science. Peter said it has good prospects and is relatively welcoming for women."

"Do you actually like it?"

Emily's voice softened. "Doesn't matter if I like it—as long as it pays well. Sis, in families like ours, who gets to talk about dreams?"

Evelyn's chest tightened. "You're so young. When did you become this pragmatic?"

"That's just reality, sis. Only the privileged get to be picky. Ordinary people like us have to focus on survival first." Emily forced a light laugh. "Anyway, gotta go—my anime just updated!"

After hanging up, Evelyn stared blankly out the window.

Peter had handled things decently—preserving both families' dignity while helping her sister with college plans.

But her sister's change broke her heart.

The girl who once rebelled for love had been worn down by reality in just one summer.

She didn’t know if this was good or bad.

Was it their circumstances forcing Emily to abandon her passions, or just the inevitable pain of growing up? Either way, it was heartbreaking.

Years from now, when Emily worked late in a lab, she might remember that summer spent obsessing over anime.

But this was the fate of ordinary people—in the relentless tide of time, even grief felt like a luxury.

"Dr. Carter! Big news!"

Olivia Lightfoot burst into the office, making Evelyn drop her pen.

"What is it?"

"That homewrecker's been hospitalized! In orthopedics, bandages all over her head. Stranger still—her parents are requesting a psych consult."

"Psychiatry?"

"Yeah! Do you think she..." Olivia made a wild gesture, "...snapped?"
###Chapter 297: The Uninvited Guest in the Parking Lot

Evelyn Carter slammed the medical record shut.

Olivia Lightfoot kept chattering, "...Her mother came in a wheelchair, looking absolutely terrible. And her father—he was so energetic last time, but today in the elevator, he looked completely hunched over..."

"Olivia."

"Huh?"

"Have you finished the post-op observation notes for Patient Three?"

"Oh no!" Olivia jumped up. "I'll go do it right now!"

The office finally fell silent.

Evelyn pulled open the drawer and retrieved the application form she had already filled out. The edges were slightly crumpled from her restless fingers.

The dean's office door was slightly ajar.

When she pushed it open, the dean was rubbing his temples in front of his computer screen. Spotting her, he quickly closed the shopping page for hair dye.

"Dean, I've prepared the materials."

"That fast?" The dean took the form, his eyes brightening behind his glasses. "The lawyer said your asset protection plan is quite innovative."

"I suggest returning the valuables first," Evelyn said calmly. "Repurchase them right before the trial."

"Natalie has everything arranged." The dean sighed in relief. "Your last outpatient shift is next Wednesday. Starting Thursday, you'll be on leave to prepare for your trip abroad."

"Mm."

"I heard your sister applied for Materials Science?" the dean suddenly asked.

Evelyn paused slightly. "Yes."

"Medical materials is a promising field." The dean smiled meaningfully. "Don’t hesitate to ask if you need any help."

As she left the office, nurses in the hallway congratulated her.

"Dr. Carter, I heard you're going to the UK for further studies?"

She nodded politely, her steps never slowing.

Fate was like a mischievous child.

Her carefully planned study abroad program had been shattered by an absurd marriage. Now that everything was finally back on track, she felt lighter, as if she could breathe easier.

Until—

Under the dim parking lot lights, the tall figure made her freeze mid-step.

He leaned against his car, the blue glow of his phone screen casting shadows on his sharp features. A cigarette burned between his fingers, its ember flickering.

Buzz—

Her phone suddenly vibrated in her pocket.
###Chapter 298: The Mask Comes Off

The phone screen lit up.

[Alexander Hamilton: Are you off work yet?]

[Alexander Hamilton: I'm waiting in the hospital parking lot.]

Evelyn Carter flipped her phone face down on the desk.

Three minutes later.

[Alexander Hamilton: If you don't come out soon, I'll come in to find you.]

She let out a cold laugh and quickly left through the hospital's back exit.

The taxi slowly pulled away from the hospital.

Alexander had finally shed his disguise.

That gentle, refined facade had only been crafted to suit Annabelle's preferences. Now the mask had shattered, revealing his ruthless nature beneath.

Evelyn knew him too well.

If he couldn't find her at the hospital, he would undoubtedly stake out her apartment.

"Driver, take me to Cicada Temple."

Cicada Temple was renowned for its spiritual potency, especially in granting health-related prayers.

After years of practicing medicine, she'd heard countless patients mention this place.

The ancient temple stood solemnly among towering pines and cypresses.

A few young monks sweeping fallen leaves clasped their hands in greeting when they saw her.

"Where can I get a protection charm?"

"The main hall."

Evelyn knelt in reverence, then carefully tucked the charm into her palm.

Familiar voices drifted in from outside the hall.

"...Praying for my daughter's well-being."

"Don't cry. We'll do our best to make amends."

"Punish me instead. Don't torment Annabelle anymore..."

"Alexander won't truly harm her, not after you saved his mother."

"I just worry no one will care for her after we're gone..."

"Maybe... we could ask Dr. Carter again?"

"But she had a miscarriage. What if she seeks revenge on Annabelle..."

"That girl has a kind heart. She wouldn't."

"It's that Yvonne we should watch out for..."

Mr. Taylor abruptly stopped speaking.

He had spotted Evelyn standing inside the hall.

"Dr. Carter!" He forced a smile and waved at her.

###Chapter 299 She's Being Haunted.

Behind Cicada Temple, nestled among rustling bamboo groves, stood an ancient pavilion.

Evelyn Carter turned to leave when Mr. Taylor called out to her.

"Dr. Carter, what a coincidence."

She paused and gave a slight nod.

Mrs. Taylor sat in her wheelchair, eyes rimmed red. "Dr. Carter, please help Annabelle..."

"Auntie, I'm an OB-GYN specialist."

"It's not that," Mr. Taylor sighed heavily. "She's being haunted."

"What?"

"Grandma Hamilton," his voice trembled. "She comes every night demanding Annabelle's life."

Evelyn frowned.

She recalled Annabelle's hysterical breakdown at the mall last week.

"There's no such thing as ghosts."

"You don't understand," Mrs. Taylor wiped her tears. "The old lady waited decades for a great-grandson, only to..."

Bamboo leaves whispered in the wind.

Evelyn's fingertips turned cold.

She'd never probed into Alexander Hamilton's past.

During their blind date, he'd been the picture of refinement—nothing like a man averse to marriage.

"She was always kind to me."

"That's because you never saw," Mr. Taylor said bitterly. "How fiercely Alexander fought her over Annabelle."

Dead leaves spiraled across the stone table.

A sudden realization struck Evelyn—she might never have truly understood the Hamiltons throughout this marriage.
###Chapter 300: The Red Thread Bracelet

Now she understood.

Evelyn finally saw the truth.

When news of Annabelle's overseas marriage reached home, Alexander Hamilton had given up all hope. That's when he accepted the arranged marriage proposed by Grandma Hamilton.

Or perhaps... it was simply because of her name.

"Grandma Hamilton never approved of our Annabelle," Mrs. Taylor sighed. "She thought Annabelle was stringing Alexander along—never saying yes, never saying no, keeping him hopeful without commitment."

Evelyn pressed her lips together.

This wasn't mere prejudice.

From Vincent Wilson and Richard Jackson, she'd heard stories about Annabelle's school days.

Not intentionally manipulative, but she'd certainly kept Alexander as a backup option.

Back then, Alexander had been content with that arrangement.

But Grandma Hamilton? A steel-willed matriarch who'd seen it all. Did anyone think she wouldn't see through a young girl's games?

"Later, you married Alexander and had a child," Mrs. Taylor's voice trembled. "When Annabelle returned after her failed marriage and reconnected with him... Dr. Carter, she never meant to break up your family. She only ever saw him as her closest friend—"

Evelyn smiled faintly. "Mm."

Mrs. Taylor exhaled in relief. "My husband was right. You're truly kind and generous, Dr. Carter. No wonder Alexander fell for you."

"Alexander and I won't reconcile," Evelyn said calmly. "I'm leaving the country soon. Even without romance, they share a lifelong bond. You needn't worry."

"But this time, Alexander's resolve is unshakable." Tears spilled down Mrs. Taylor's cheeks. "Grandma Hamilton passed without final words because of Annabelle. And that child... Dr. Carter, his feelings for you are real—"

"Auntie." Evelyn cut her off. "I understand parental love. But are other people's daughters less precious? I was also cherished by my parents."

Mrs. Taylor flustered. "I'm sorry, I didn't mean—"

Mr. Taylor suddenly fixed his gaze on Evelyn's wrist. "This... is yours?"

Evelyn glanced at the red thread bracelet.

A childhood talisman from her parents, worn today to reassure them before her departure.

"It's just an ordinary protection charm—"

Before she could finish, Mrs. Taylor seized her wrist.

The red thread dug into flesh. Evelyn gasped at the sharp pain.

"Auntie, you're hurting me—"

"Terry... You're Terry..." Mr. Taylor's voice shook, tears streaming down his weathered face. "It's really you..."
###Chapter 301: The Warmth of Blood Ties

Evelyn Carter stood at the front door, her fingertips trembling slightly.

The sound of the lock turning alerted Grace Anderson inside. She hurried to open the door. "You're back! Come in, I'll heat up dinner for you."

The faint scent of cooking oil drifted from the kitchen.

Six small bowls were neatly lined up by the stove, each dish carefully wrapped in plastic film.

"Mom, so much food..."

Grace deftly removed the plastic. "Your favorite braised ribs, and Emily's sweet and sour fish. The soup was just made this afternoon—best served hot."

The range hood hummed softly.

Her mother's figure flickered in the haze of cooking fumes, the silver strands at her temples stark under the light.

"Mom."

"Hmm?" Grace kept her eyes on the sizzling pan. "Did you wash your hands? Dinner's almost ready."

Evelyn didn't move.

Grace finally noticed something was off and turned to look. "What's wrong? Work too exhausting?"

From the living room, Andrew Anderson called out, "Evelyn's home? Come help me with this."

She stepped into the bedroom.

Her father sat by the desk lamp, flipping through bankbooks with his reading glasses on.

"Dad."

He motioned for her to sit. "Perfect timing. Help me calculate if this is enough."

The edges of the bankbooks were slightly curled.

"This is..."

"You're leaving for England next month," he said in a hushed tone. "I've been saving up secretly. Don't tell your mom."

Her nose stung.

"Everything's expensive there. Heard a bowl of noodles costs dozens of pounds. A young woman shouldn't skimp on necessities."

"Dad, the hospital will cover room and board."

He shook his head stubbornly. "You still need pocket money. New clothes, dinners with colleagues—can't let them think our girls are stingy."

The lamplight cast a warm glow on his hands.

Calloused yet gentle, they smoothed the creased corners of the bankbooks.

"Dad, I might... stay there to work."

He paused briefly, then smiled. "Even better. But if you get homesick, come back anytime. Your room will always be here."

"What about Emily's tuition..."

"Don't worry about that." He patted her hand. "Just spread your wings. Your mom and I have everything handled."

Evelyn suddenly hugged him.

Andrew patted her back gently. "Silly child. A parent's love is instinctive. Have you ever seen a tree that doesn't cherish its fruit?"

The clinking of dishes sounded from the kitchen.

Grace called out, "Evelyn, dinner's ready—"

At that moment, something burned fiercely in Evelyn's chest.
###Chapter 302: The Blood Type Mystery

The red thread bracelet grew warm against her wrist.

Evelyn Carter stared at it for a long moment, her fingertips brushing the faded knot.

"Why are you wearing that again?" Andrew Anderson emerged from the kitchen with a teacup, his gaze dropping to her wrist.

"Mom said it brings good luck."

"Good," Andrew nodded. "You were always sick as a child. This seemed to help."

"Dad, where did you buy this?"

"That was over twenty years ago. Who remembers?" He waved a hand dismissively. "Nobody wears these anymore. Gold and silver are trendy now."

Evelyn lowered her lashes. "Does Emily have one?"

"She wasn't even born then!" Andrew suddenly remembered something. "Oh, check these bankbooks for me."

Four passbooks lay spread on the coffee table.

Evelyn verified each one. "Twenty-eight thousand and six hundred in total."

"See? I knew I remembered right." He pulled out three. "Converted to pounds, this should cover your studies abroad."

"Dad—"

"Don't argue. Consider it an investment." His voice dropped. "Why did you need the household register?"

"Visa application."

His expression relaxed. "I thought..." He trailed off, then retrieved the booklet from the bedroom. "Return it immediately after."

"Understood."

The deep red cover felt cold against her fingertips.

When the bedroom door clicked shut, she drew a deep breath.

The rustle of paper echoed sharply in the silence.

Andrew Anderson: Type O.
Grace Anderson: Type O.
Evelyn Carter: Type O.
Emily Anderson: Type O.

Her eyes lingered on the blood type column.

"Evelyn! Dinner!" Grace's voice pierced through the door.

Evelyn closed the booklet, her palms damp.

At the table, Andrew asked abruptly, "The education section still lists high school. Will that be a problem?"

"No." She picked at her greens. "The visa mainly checks residency details."

Grace handed her a bowl of soup. "You seem distracted."

"Just thinking about the hospital."

Andrew snorted. "Did you run into that Hamilton boy again? I saw him downstairs today and sent him packing."

Her spoon clinked against the bowl.

"What was he doing here?"

"What else?" Andrew slammed his chopsticks down. "I warned him to stay away!"

Evelyn sipped her soup, steam blurring her vision.

Type O was a recessive gene.

The fact circled relentlessly in her mind.

After dinner, she stood on the balcony, letting the night air cool her skin.

The breeze stirred the red thread bracelet—a silent accusation.
###Chapter 303: The Blood Type Mystery

Morning sunlight filtered through the curtains as Evelyn Carter stood dressed and ready.

She lingered at the hospital lab entrance, fingers absently tracing the blood collection tube in her white coat pocket.

"Dr. Carter, you're early," a yawning colleague greeted while unlocking the door.

"Urgent test."

"That pressing?"

"Yes."

The centrifuge hummed, spinning glass vials of blood in dizzying circles.

When the report printed, her fingertips trembled slightly.

Type A.

Those two letters stabbed into her memory like a blade.

"Dr. Carter?" Dr. Porter's voice snapped her back. "You look pale."

She folded the paper sharply. "Just low blood sugar."

"Bed 53's results aren't ready yet. Maybe rest in the lounge?"

"No need."

Once the hallway emptied, she shredded the report to confetti.

As scraps fluttered into the trash, Anthony Taylor's broken voice echoed in her mind: "We searched for our daughter over twenty years..."

......

The dean's call came unexpectedly.

"Evelyn, Hudson City needs you sooner. Can you relocate early?"

Her desk calendar still showed last week's date.

She turned a page quietly. "Understood."

Natalie Stapleton's hospital room smelled of chicken soup.

"Evelyn!" The girl's rounded cheeks glowed as she gestured to a thermos. "Mom made ginseng broth today."

Evelyn smoothed the sheets. "Your color's better."

"Dad's force-feeding me five meals daily." Natalie whispered, "I've gained five pounds."

"That's progress." She tucked in the blanket corners. "How's recovery?"

"Perfect!" Natalie suddenly gripped her hand. "The court summons arrived. Trial's next month."

The door handle turned mid-sentence.

"Mom, you're early—" Natalie's voice choked.

Simon Stapleton's greasy smile appeared in the doorway.

Evelyn blocked the bed instantly. "Get out!"

"Now, now." He rubbed his hands. "Just checking on my wife—"

"Security!"

"Unnecessary." A baritone voice interrupted. "I brought him."

Alexander Hamilton stepped inside, his tailored suit immaculate.

Simon scrambled aside. "After you, Mr. Hamilton."

Natalie clutched the sheets. "Mr. Hamilton?"

Evelyn felt the girl trembling behind her.

"My apologies." Alexander's gaze swept the room before settling on Evelyn. "May we enter?"
###Chapter 304: You—Come With Me

Natalie's fingers twisted together nervously as her gaze darted between Simon and Alexander.

"Mr. Hamilton, this..."

Alexander stood with one hand in his pocket, completely at ease. "Don't worry, Miss Stapleton. He won’t cause any trouble today."

Evelyn braced herself against the doorframe, her nails digging into the wood. "Explain yourself before you come in."

"You really want me to say it now?" Alexander leaned in slightly, his breath brushing against her ear.

Evelyn jerked back half a step. "Don't you dare—"

"I missed you."

The words hit her like a thunderclap. Her fists clenched, knuckles turning white. "Missed me? So you brought him as an excuse?"

"What else could I do?" Alexander gave a bitter smile. "You’ve been avoiding me like the plague—changing shifts, dodging me at the hospital, even steering clear of your own apartment. If I hadn’t seized this chance, would you have even looked at me?"

Evelyn scoffed. "At least you’re self-aware."

"Which is why I had to corner you here." Alexander turned to Natalie with a slight nod. "Apologies for the intrusion."

Natalie stood awkwardly to the side, her eyes flickering between them.

Simon was already pulling a stack of documents from his briefcase. "Natalie, just sign here. Mr. Hamilton said he’d handle the paperwork—we can get the divorce certificate today!"

"Really?" Natalie’s eyes lit up as she looked at Alexander. "But your mother—"

"Don’t worry," Simon cut in, rubbing his hands together eagerly. "I’ll deal with my mom. Lora can’t wait—her family’s influential, we need to hurry with the wedding—"

"Wait!" Evelyn snatched the papers from him, flipping through the pages. "Forty pages?"

Alexander leaned against the doorframe, his gaze dark. "Not everyone gets a three-minute divorce like we did."

Evelyn’s fingers stilled.

Back then, she’d mailed the signed papers and received the divorce certificate within a week. He and Annabelle had been inseparable—no doubt he’d been desperate to cut ties.

"What about the asset division?"

"Everything goes to Natalie!" Simon blurted. "I’ll walk away with nothing! Lora’s pregnant, and her family—"

"What?!" Evelyn’s head snapped up, her eyes wide as she stared at Alexander. "Lora’s pregnant?"

Alexander adjusted his cufflinks leisurely. "Want to know?"

Suddenly, he grabbed Evelyn’s wrist. The moment Natalie finished signing, he pulled Evelyn into his arms.

"Now," he said, his voice low. "Come with me."
###Chapter 305: I Don't Want What You Give

Natalie's hand trembled slightly as she held the pen, hesitating to sign.

"Evelyn..."

Evelyn met Alexander's gaze directly. "Can you guarantee this contract is foolproof?"

The corner of Alexander's mouth lifted. "Don't you trust Hamilton Group's legal team?"

"Wasn't Yvonne Young also part of your legal team?"

His eyes darkened. "She's been dealt with."

"What about the two apartments she promised? Do those still stand?"

Alexander chuckled. "Are you really short on property?"

"Yes." Evelyn nodded seriously. "The locations and layouts are good."

"I thought you didn't want anything from me."

"I don't."

"Do the apartments I give come with man-eating monsters?"

"Maybe not monsters, but definitely unwanted visitors."

Alexander laughed lowly. "I'll take responsibility for the contract. Contact me if there are any issues."

Natalie whispered, "Evelyn, since Mr. Hamilton has assured us..."

Something still felt off to Evelyn.

"Mr. Hamilton, can we rephrase that?"

"Hmm?"

"I don't want to contact you."

Alexander's gaze deepened as he studied her.

Simon rubbed his hands anxiously. "Natalie, hurry up and sign. I have an important appointment this afternoon..."

"What appointment?"

Alexander said coolly, "Mr. Sun invited Simon for tea."

Evelyn's heart skipped a beat.

Lora might be a fake heiress, but Mr. Sun was a titan of the business world. Getting his attention must have cost Alexander dearly.

"Evelyn?" Natalie held out the pen.

Evelyn took a deep breath. "Sign it."

Natalie signed swiftly and pushed the agreement back. "From now on, we go our separate ways."

Simon was already dreaming of his windfall. "Don't worry, I'll pretend I don't know you if we meet. Lora gets jealous—she threw a fit for days when she found out I was married before..."

Natalie smirked. "Then I hope you two stay together forever. Don't inflict yourselves on anyone else."

Simon eagerly handed the papers to Alexander. "Mr. Hamilton, the divorce certificate..."

Alexander dialed his secretary.

After hanging up, he said flatly, "It'll be delivered to you tomorrow."

"Thank you so much!" Simon grabbed Alexander's hand excitedly. "You're the Stapleton family's savior..."

Alexander pulled his hand away in disgust. "Thank yourself. You're the one who charmed Lora into this."
###Chapter 306: Never Try to Guess a Man's Mind

Simon Stapleton rubbed his hands smugly and leaned toward Alexander Hamilton, whispering, "Mr. Hamilton, want me to teach you a few tricks? Guaranteed to win Dr. Carter back."

Alexander tilted his head slightly. "Oh?"

"Dealing with women requires strategy." Simon winked. "I'm an expert in this field."

"Simon Stapleton!" Evelyn Carter slammed the table and stood abruptly. "You're not welcome here!"

Simon flinched before pouting. "Dr. Carter, you should work on that temper. A high-value man like Mr. Hamilton giving you a second chance—you should be thrilled—"

Natalie Stapleton grabbed his collar and dragged him out. "Get lost!"

"Hey—easy there—"

The door slammed shut. Simon's fading curses echoed down the hall.

Natalie squeezed Evelyn's hand. "Evelyn..."

Evelyn forced a smile. "At least we won’t have to go through a lawsuit."

"Yeah." Natalie pulled out her phone. "I'll contact Vivian right away to liquidate those luxury items. Mr. Hamilton's secretary said the divorce certificate will be ready this afternoon."

Evelyn nodded. "Go ahead."

Before leaving, Natalie cast a worried glance at Alexander on the couch.

"Don't worry," Evelyn murmured.

As the door closed again, the air turned suffocating.

Alexander's gaze burned against her profile.

Evelyn stiffly flipped open her medical chart, the pages trembling slightly in her grip.

"Won't even look at me now?"

Her eyes remained fixed on the notes. "You came to me."

His shadow loomed over her, the familiar citrus scent enveloping her.

Only now did she realize how naive she'd been—to ever mistake him for a gentle soul. No man could dominate the business world without a ruthless core.

"Did you arrange Lora's pregnancy?"

Alexander chuckled darkly. "Finally asking?"

"Leave innocent people out of this."

"Fake." His admission was blunt. "The test results were photoshopped."

Evelyn frowned. "Simon would believe that?"

He suddenly leaned in, his breath grazing her ear. "Evelyn, you don't understand men. For some, knocking up a woman on the first try is a badge of honor. He'll be too busy gloating to question it."

His voice dropped to a dangerous murmur. "Just like I once did."
###Chapter 307: Threatening Me Again?

"I truly don't understand."

Alexander Hamilton chuckled softly. "No fault of yours. You lack experience."

"Mhm. This trip abroad will be good practice."

His gaze darkened instantly. "Evelyn, the more you say such things in anger, the more it proves you still care."

"Gold may be precious, but not everyone covets it."

Alexander sighed deeply. "Evelyn, I don't know how to handle you anymore. Kindness doesn't work, and I can't bear to be harsh. Just name your terms. If it's within my power, let's start over."

"No terms. Because it's impossible."

"There must be something." His fingers tapped lightly on the divorce papers. "Whether this document goes to the civil affairs office or the shredder depends entirely on you."

Evelyn's chest heaved violently. "You're pulling this stunt again?"

"I don't want to. But I have no choice. Crude as it is, it works."

"Have you considered that Natalie Stapleton is no relation of mine? I could easily stand aside and wait for the court's verdict."

"Of course you could." His eyes turned icy. "And I could have Lora withdraw her investment immediately."

Evelyn shot to her feet. "You—"

"Then what did you come here to say?"

"Give me a chance. Don't reject me outright."

Evelyn scoffed.

"About Annabelle... I need to explain. We grew up—"

"I know all that. No need to repeat it."

He paused. "Something happened when we were children. Her mother did our family a great kindness. I'll look after her, but I won't let her interfere in my life again."

"What if she tries another approach? Like playing the tragic heroine, weeping and begging for sympathy?"

"Tragic heroines have their own devoted lovers. What's that to me?" His tone was firm. "I only promised Aunt Lin I'd ensure her daughter's wellbeing. Nothing more."

Evelyn frowned slightly. "Aunt Lin?"

"Annabelle's mother's maiden name is Taylor, but I've always called her Aunt Lin. Old habit."

She drew a slow breath. "So you're only taking care of Annabelle out of obligation?"

"Exactly. To me now, she's just Aunt Lin's daughter."

"What if Aunt Lin had other children?"

"Same treatment. Only what's necessary."

"..."

"Evelyn, why ask this?"

"No reason." She changed the subject. "Get Natalie's divorce certificate finalized quickly. Best to end this before Simon realizes he's been tricked."

Alexander nodded. "Done. Then consider my request agreed to."
###Chapter 308: Cool Down with Some Skeletons!

"Let's get the paperwork done first."

He chuckled low. "Fine."

"I'm leaving if there's nothing else."

His strong arm suddenly tightened around her waist, trapping her.

Evelyn struggled, but he only pulled her closer against his chest.

"Alexander Hamilton!" she hissed under her breath. "We're in a hospital!"

"Stop moving."

"Are you insane? Let go!"

She froze.

She could feel the unmistakable change in his body pressed against her.

"Six months," he rasped, voice rough. "Do you have any idea how hard I've held back?"

"Not my problem!"

"Before, I was afraid of scaring you—always restraining myself..." His lips brushed her earlobe. "Not anymore."

"Oh?"

"Don’t believe me? Fine."

"Where are we going?"

"You’ll see."

They stopped in front of a white door.

He raised a brow. "Urology?"

"Yes." She forced a neutral tone. "There are... educational tools inside."

His gaze lingered on her before he pushed the door open.

Seizing the moment, Evelyn yanked her wrist free and shoved him inside.

Bang!

The door locked behind him.

"Evelyn!" His fist pounded against the wood.

She exhaled in relief. "It’s the anatomy lab. Enjoy bonding with the skeletons!"

Silence.

Just as she frowned, her phone buzzed.

A photo from Alexander—

Him standing in front of a row of human skeletons, flashing a peace sign.

[Perfectly calm now. Care to join the tour?]

She nearly threw her phone across the hall.

This absolute menace!
###Chapter 309: Thank You, Uncle

The last rays of sunset filtered through the blinds, casting golden stripes across the desk.

Evelyn Carter was intently helping Olivia Lightfoot revise the data analysis section of her thesis.

A loud bang shattered the quiet.

The office door flew open.

Olivia sprang up like a coiled spring. "Emergency? Which bed?"

Evelyn glanced at the visitor and said calmly, "Third floor of the annex. Left at the end. Key's under the flowerpot on the windowsill."

The woman's tense shoulders visibly relaxed. "Thanks."

She turned to leave.

"Wait."

The woman paused mid-step.

"Don't forget the file folder on bedside table 54."

"Got it."

The woman disappeared as abruptly as she'd arrived.

Olivia blinked in confusion. "Dr. Carter, who was that?"

"An acquaintance."

"Family member of a former patient?"

"No."

Olivia's eyes widened. "Wait—isn't the end of the third floor the specimen room?" Then it clicked. "Oh! The new janitor from housekeeping?"

"Your literature review has issues." Evelyn tapped the screen. "Come look."

Olivia hurried over.

Evelyn massaged her temples.

She loved clinical work but loathed paperwork.

Promotion reviews required reports. Research papers demanded write-ups. Even year-end summaries needed documentation.

Just as she'd caught her breath, Olivia's thesis revisions landed on her plate.

Knowing she'd soon be leaving made her want to give this diligent intern a solid foundation.

Few attending physicians took time to mentor juniors in academic writing.

Olivia pouted. "Dr. Carter, what'll I do when you're gone?"

"You'll learn independence."

Olivia puffed her cheeks. "Then I'll apply for the next rotation transfer. Come study under you."

"Sure. I'll be waiting."

Knock-knock.

The door sounded again.

Olivia grinned. "Specimen duty's all yours!"

The woman ignored her, gaze fixed on Evelyn.

Evelyn raised a brow. "Yes?"

"Message from Mr. Hamilton."

"Go on."

"He says if you lose any more weight, you'll qualify as a medical specimen."

"......"

"Natalie Stapleton's divorce papers will be processed tomorrow morning. I'll bring them during lunch."

"Appreciate it."

Only after the woman left did Olivia process this. "Dr. Carter, how'd she know about Natalie's divorce? Is she from admin? But why would admin staff go to the specimen room?"

Evelyn tapped the keyboard. "Do you want this discussion section revised or not?"

"Ugh! I hate theses! Whoever invented them belongs on medicine's darkest page!"

......

At shift's end, Evelyn dialed home. "Mom, don't wait dinner for me."

The taxi carried her once more to Cicada Temple.

The vegetarian restaurant beside the temple exuded antique charm.

A server guided her to a private room.

Anthony Taylor and Teresa Taylor had been waiting.

Teresa's hands trembled with emotion. She tried standing but faltered, eyes glistening as she stared hungrily at Evelyn.

Anthony's eyes also reddened. Seeing his wife stumble, he rushed to steady her.

Teresa waved him off. "I'm fine. Terry's here—sit, sit! Anthony, help our daughter with her..."

Anthony moved to take Evelyn's bag.

Evelyn hung it directly on the coat hook by the door.

"Thank you, Uncle. This is fine."
###Chapter 310: The Bloodline Puzzle

The word "uncle" caught in Anthony Taylor's throat.

He opened his mouth but only managed a soft sigh. "Please, have a seat."

The private dining room felt cavernous with only the ten-seat round table occupying it.

Teresa Taylor's wheelchair stopped beside the table as Anthony pulled out two chairs for her.

Evelyn Carter's gaze lingered on the seats across from them before she walked over without hesitation.

Teresa's eyes instantly welled up.

Anthony gave his wife's shoulder a comforting pat, murmuring something inaudible.

"Have you ordered yet?"

"Not yet," Anthony's voice trembled slightly. "We weren't sure what you'd like. Terry, please order anything you want. Mom and Dad—"

Evelyn flipped open the menu, her fingers tightening imperceptibly.

The vegetarian restaurant offered exquisite dishes at premium prices.

She mechanically checked two items before pressing the service bell.

"You like tofu?" Teresa suddenly asked.

"Just random choices."

"But two of the three dishes you picked are tofu-based..."

Evelyn closed the menu. "I assume today's conversation isn't about food?"

Tears spilled down Teresa's cheeks.

"How can our first meal with our daughter be random? Anthony, go order every tofu dish on the menu!"

Anthony hurried out with red-rimmed eyes.

The delicate aroma of tea rose between them.

Evelyn stood to pour Teresa a cup.

Teresa accepted it with both hands, her fingertips visibly shaking.

"Terry," she sipped tentatively, "do you usually drink tea?"

"Occasionally."

"What do you prefer then? Coffee? Bubble tea? I'll have Anthony fetch—"

"Auntie," Evelyn met her gaze directly, "a red string bracelet proves nothing."

Silence engulfed the room.

Teresa gripped her teacup tightly before blurting out, "There's something... I hope you won't be angry."

"What is it?"

"After losing our daughter for twenty-four years, that night we saw the bracelet..." She hesitated. "We couldn't sleep. To confirm, we... took some of your hair for a DNA test."

Evelyn's fingers stilled.

"Results don't come that fast."

"We pulled strings. The report arrives tomorrow afternoon."

"My hair?" Evelyn's brow furrowed slightly. "When?"

Teresa looked stricken.

"During our first meeting in the neighborhood, you hadn't seen the bracelet yet. At Cicada Temple, I don't recall shedding any."

"It was..." Teresa's voice dwindled to a whisper. "We went to your marital home with Alexander."

Evelyn suddenly laughed.

"But Annabelle lived there too. How can you be sure it was mine?"
###Chapter 311: The Secret Kept Close

"We could tell because those strands of hair weren't randomly collected."

Teresa Taylor's voice trembled slightly.

"They were stored in a... special place."

"What kind of place?"

"A ring box."

Evelyn Carter's fingertips tightened imperceptibly.

"Annabelle once mentioned that Alexander always carried a ring box with him, never letting it out of his sight. Once, out of curiosity, she tried to open it, but before she could even touch it, he caught her."

Teresa recalled the scene vividly.

"He'd never been so furious before. He scared Annabelle to tears."

Evelyn lowered her gaze.

"So Emily Zade helped you?"

"Yes, but not in the way you think."

Teresa hurried to explain.

"Emily has been loyal to Alexander all these years. But she had a good impression of you. She only agreed to help after we explained our purpose."

Evelyn frowned slightly.

"How much did you tell her?"

"Just that we wanted to run a test. Nothing else was mentioned."

The air grew heavy with silence.

"Terry, after that day at Cicada Temple, we understood..."

Teresa's voice choked with emotion.

"You didn’t want to acknowledge us. After all these years of failing to find you, it’s only natural you’d resent us..."

"I don’t resent you."

Evelyn met her eyes directly.

"I just don’t remember. In my memory, there are only my adoptive parents. They scrimped and saved to put me through school, poured everything into buying me a home. They are my real parents."
