Evelyn cut her off.

"...I know."

Teresa bowed her head.

"I have a few more questions."

Evelyn took a deep breath.

"What if the test proves I’m not your daughter?"

"Impossible! That red thread bracelet was woven by my own hands!"

"Just hypothetically."

Teresa suddenly stood up.

"May I see your forehead?"

"Why?"

"There should be a faint scar above your left brow. You got it when you fell at four years old."

Evelyn froze in place.

"It seems you already have your answer."

Teresa smiled bitterly as she sat back down.

"What’s your second question?"

"How old was your daughter when she went missing?"

"Four years and three months."

"At that age, she should have had memories."

Evelyn’s voice was soft.

"But I have no recollection of you at all. Only my adoptive parents."

Tears finally spilled down Teresa’s cheeks.

"That’s what pains me most. Back then, we turned H City upside down, checked every mode of transportation..."

Her voice grew fainter.

"It was as if you’d vanished into thin air."
###Chapter 312: The Only Request

The private investigator's report remains vividly etched in my mind.

"A four-year-old missing for this long was most likely abducted," he told us back then.

But all we received was endless silence.

Three months later, the police gently suggested there was little hope.

Teresa Taylor suddenly broke down, covering her face as tears streamed through her fingers.

Anthony Taylor quickly stepped forward, pulling his wife into his arms. "Don't cry. Our daughter has returned. That's a good thing..."

"It's all my fault," Teresa's voice shattered. "If only I'd watched her more closely that day..."

Anthony patted his wife's back, his own eyes red-rimmed when he turned to me. "She almost... all these years... Thank goodness we adopted Annabelle later..."

The teacup trembled slightly in my hand, spilling droplets onto the table.

I pulled out a tissue and mechanically wiped the surface.

"One last question."

"Go ahead."

"Did Alexander Hamilton and I know each other as children?"

Anthony froze. "We moved next to the Hamiltons a year after adopting Annabelle."

He paused. "Alexander was very excited back then, talking about some promise... Later, he treated Annabelle exceptionally well..."

"He mistook her for me?"

"...Possibly. Annabelle wore all your old clothes..."

I took a deep breath, my chest heavy as if weighed down by a stone.

"What's wrong?" Anthony asked with concern.

"Nothing."

"There are no outsiders here. You can say anything."

"Aside from Emily Zade, who else knows my true identity?"

"Not for now. But once the paternity test results come out, we must—"

"No need." I cut him off. "I have just one request."

"Name it."

"Keep this secret. Forever."
###Chapter 313: The Fork in Fate

Anthony Taylor's hands trembled slightly. "Sweetheart, are you blaming us?"

Teresa Taylor's tears soaked her collar. "I know I was wrong. I've regretted it every single day. You can hate me, but please don't deny us..."

"My current parents have been wonderful to me." I gripped my water glass. "They sacrificed everything to raise me. I won't let them suffer the pain of losing a daughter in their old age."

Teresa clutched my wrist desperately. "But blood ties can't be severed!"

"Blood matters, but the debt of upbringing matters more."

Silence filled the private dining room.

Teresa suddenly remembered something. "What about Alexander? You two were perfect for each other..."

"We're over." I cut her off. "Some fractures can never be mended."

Anthony slammed his teacdown with force. "Fine! We respect your decision."

Teresa stared at her husband in disbelief.

"But one request," Anthony's voice cracked. "Could we...see you sometimes?"

"I'm leaving for further studies in the UK."

Teresa's glass shattered on the floor.

"When?" Anthony's words shook.

"Next month."

Teresa beat her own thighs in anguish. "These useless legs! I can't even visit my own daughter..."

Anthony knelt beside her, clasping her hands. "I'll carry you onto planes. I'll wheel you around the world. Anywhere you want to go."

Watching this couple past their prime, my chest tightened.

"We can video call." The words escaped before I realized.

Teresa jerked her head up, tears still glistening. "Really?"

"Medical work keeps me busy. It won't be frequent."

Tears turned to tremulous smiles. "Yes, yes! You focus on your career. Just seeing your face would be enough..."

Waiters began serving, covering the table with exquisite dishes.

Anthony's unsteady hands placed food on my plate. "Try this. Your father remembers how much you loved fish as a child..."

"Terry," Teresa ventured timidly, "before you leave...could you come home for one meal?"

Surveying the lavish spread, I gave a small nod.
###Chapter 314 The Perfect Distance

Evelyn set down her chopsticks and said softly, "I might not make it in time."

"I see..."

"Yeah."

Teresa smiled gently. "It's alright. We can have it when you return."

"...We'll see."

"Or perhaps your father could cook for you abroad?" Teresa's eyes sparkled with hope. "Foreign food never quite compares to home cooking."

Anthony immediately chimed in, "Yes, your mother and I could come take care of you. Don't worry—we won't disturb your work. Just cooking and tidying up."

The sudden outpouring of familial affection caught Evelyn off guard.

Her silence made Anthony and Teresa tread even more carefully. They hesitated to even pick up food, afraid of displeasing her.

The meal was unusually tense.

As they left, Anthony asked the server to pack the leftovers. "You can reheat these later. Saves you the trouble of cooking."

"My mom prepares dinner every day."

Anthony's hand froze mid-air. He forced an awkward smile. "Right. I forgot you go home for meals."

"Yeah."

"Then... we'll take them." He quickly backtracked, anxious not to upset her. "No pressure at all."

Evelyn asked, "Are you heading back to the hospital?"

"Yes. Annabelle is still recovering—her injuries were quite severe..." Teresa hurried to explain, "Evelyn, please don't misunderstand. You're our biological daughter—that will never change. But we raised Annabelle, and now that Alexander has abandoned her, we can't just turn our backs."

"I don't mind." Evelyn picked up her bag. "Take care of her. I should go."

...

In the following days, Teresa sent daily morning and evening texts.

Simple messages—just asking if work was busy or if she was tired.

During lunch breaks in the cafeteria, Evelyn often spotted Anthony from a distance. If their eyes met, he'd smile and nod.

They maintained the perfect distance.

Evelyn breathed a quiet sigh of relief. It seemed they'd taken her words to heart.

She didn’t want her current life disrupted, and they understood boundaries.

At home, everything remained normal. Grace cooked her favorite dishes with creative flair. Andrew insisted she take extra money. Emily clung to her, crying like a child. "Sis, you and Peter are both leaving. When school starts, I’ll be all alone..."

Grace comforted, "Your dad and I will be with you."

"I know," Emily sniffled. "I just don’t want to say goodbye to my sister."

Andrew chuckled and shook his head. "No backbone! Your sister handled college all on her own."

"How can I compare to her? She’s my one and only sister!"

Evelyn hugged her sister, a sudden ache in her chest. "I’ll visit when I can. You can come see me during summer break."

"Really?" Emily’s eyes lit up. "I’ll definitely go!"

Grace hesitated. "International flights aren’t cheap, and your school expenses..."

Evelyn gently nudged her mother’s arm.

But Andrew said firmly, "Evelyn, your sister’s grown up. She needs to face reality."

Evelyn understood.

Yet she still wanted to shield Emily from life’s storms.

This time, Emily surprised her with maturity. "It’s okay, sis. If I can’t visit, you’ll come back for New Year’s, right? We’ll celebrate as a family."
###Chapter 315: So I Was the Fool All Along

"Evelyn, the overseas assignment pays double! Come visit me this summer—I'll cover all your expenses."

Emily Anderson shook her head like a windmill. "No way! You work so hard for that money. I'll just video call you."

Evelyn Carter ruffled her sister's hair. "My little girl's growing up."

After dinner, Emily insisted on going home with her.

The girl had always been clingy, trailing after her like a shadow since childhood.

Evelyn's heart softened, and she took her sister back to the apartment.

Late at night, Emily curled up against her, voice muffled. "Evelyn... he came to see me today."

"Hmm?"

"My... ex-boyfriend."

It took Evelyn a moment to remember—the boy who'd nearly torn Emily from their family.

Strange how she'd already forgotten his name when it hadn't been that long.

"What did he say?"

Emily scoffed. "Called me a gold-digger for not following him to Beijing. Said I'd regret it when he made it big."

"How do you feel?"

Emily burrowed deeper into her embrace. "At first I was upset—like I'd given up too soon. Then I realized... what's love compared to having you, Mom, Dad, and my best friends? Wouldn't I be an idiot to abandon you all for some guy?"

Evelyn patted her back. "I'm not the best person for relationship advice."

"Are you kidding?" Emily lifted her face. "You married Alexander, then dated Peter! You're practically an expert!"

Evelyn smiled bitterly.

Her marriage to Alexander Hamilton had fast-forwarded straight to polite coexistence—they'd never even properly dated.

As for Peter Harrison...

That was nothing but an elaborate con.

If she hadn't kept her wits about her, she'd be worse off than Natalie Stapleton by now.

"Honestly, I envy you. Getting to experience pure love at your age."

"Regretting not dating in high school?"

"Not regret... just acknowledging life's trade-offs."

"Like what happened to Vivian? Destroying herself for love?"

Evelyn pinched her sister's cheek. "You got lucky—that boy was amateur hour."

Emily blinked smugly. "Or maybe I was just too smart for him?"

"Well..."

"Evelyn! I'm your sister! I might not be as brilliant as you, but I'm not far behind!"

Studying Emily's bright eyes, Evelyn felt a sudden disorientation.

She resembled their mother—gentle and delicate.

Emily took after their father, with round cheeks and an endearing playfulness.

Ding—

A phone notification chimed.

Probably Teresa Taylor's nightly check-in.

Emily grabbed the device lightning-fast. "Who is it?"

Evelyn tensed. "Probably the hospital..."

"Nope." Emily waved the glowing screen. "Someone named Alexander Hamilton."
###Chapter 316: Karma

"It's a message from Vivian."

Emily handed over her phone.

A single line of text glowed on the screen:
[Vivian: Evelyn, call me ASAP.]

Evelyn took the phone and strode toward the balcony. "Rest for now. I need to make a call."

The call connected instantly.

Vivian's voice carried unusual gravity. "Something terrible happened."

"What is it?"

"Simon's mother is dead."

Evelyn's grip tightened around the phone. "When?"

"This afternoon. After Lora disappeared, the people Simon scammed came for him. He'd taken bribes pretending to be Oceanic Group's son-in-law. Now that the engagement's off..."

Evelyn glanced at the inky darkness beyond the window.

Despite the summer heat, a chill ran down her spine.

"Those people..."

"Took his mother hostage. Things went wrong." Vivian paused. "She died on the spot."

Evelyn drew a sharp breath. "Did they call the police?"

"He wouldn't dare. The fraud charges alone would put him away for life."

"How could he be so reckless? Even if he'd married into the Hardy family, old Mr. Hardy would never let him control anything."

Vivian scoffed. "Conning women became second nature to him. Pregnancy, marriage, extortion—his usual playbook. Natalie was too easy. He started thinking all women were that gullible."

"Now that he's desperate, do you think—"

"He'll go after Natalie?" Vivian snorted. "The hospital director's waiting for him. So are his creditors."

Silence stretched between them.

"Are you okay?" Evelyn asked softly.

"Couldn't be better. Justice is served." Yet exhaustion laced Vivian's words.

"But you don't sound happy."

"..." A long sigh. "Ten years ago, I might've set off fireworks to celebrate. But now..."

Her voice faded. "My college entrance exams... my future... none of that can be undone."

"You saved Natalie."

"I saved my younger self." Vivian suddenly laughed. "By the way, Dad's sixtieth birthday is this weekend. You're coming."

"I'll be there."

Hanging up, Evelyn gazed at the distant city lights.

Karma always collects its due.

But the price it exacts sometimes cuts too deep.
###Chapter 317: The Birthday Banquet

The Dempsey villa was adorned with festive decorations on Saturday.

Evelyn Carter arrived half an hour early. The Dempsey servants bustled about, arranging trays as they prepared the venue.

Vivian Dempsey wore a lilac mermaid gown, her curls elegantly pinned up, makeup flawless—yet she looked utterly wilted, like frostbitten foliage.

"Evelyn!" Her eyes brightened at the sight of her friend.

Evelyn handed her a meticulously wrapped gift box.

"Wow, a Tudor watch?" Vivian weighed it in her palm. "This is too extravagant."

"It's only right." Evelyn studied her. "Why so glum?"

Vivian tugged at her skirt. "See this dress?"

"It suits you."

"That's not the point!" Vivian groaned dramatically. "My dad suddenly decided to throw a sixtieth birthday bash. Doesn't that strike you as odd? He's at the gym every day, more energetic than I am."

Evelyn's eyes widened in realization. "A matchmaking event?"

Vivian looked ready to cry. "Bingo."

"Parents will be parents." Evelyn patted her shoulder in consolation.

Vivian suddenly lowered her voice. "By the way, Dad mentioned Alexander Hamilton was injured and couldn't make it. When did that happen?"

Evelyn's smile froze. "I wouldn't know."

"You haven't contacted him?"

"Blocked."

"Strange." Vivian frowned. "That doesn't sound like him."

Guests began arriving in steady streams.

Amid the glittering crowd, Evelyn recognized several business elites.

Mr. Dempsey dragged his daughter around, enthusiastically introducing her to every eligible bachelor. Vivian looked utterly defeated, casting desperate glances toward Evelyn.

Evelyn retreated to a corner with her orange juice, searching for an opportunity to rescue her friend when a familiar grip closed around her wrist.

"Don't move."

The voice sent a jolt through her.

Alexander Hamilton settled beside her, leisurely adjusting his cufflinks. "Surprised?"

"You said you weren't coming."

"Changed my mind."

Just then, Anthony Taylor wheeled Teresa Taylor into the room. The couple, dressed impeccably, lit up at the sight of Evelyn. "Evel— Oh, Alexander's here too."
###Chapter 318: Scars

Alexander Hamilton clearly didn't expect to encounter Anthony and Teresa Taylor here. He gave a slight bow. "Mr. Taylor, Mrs. Taylor."

Teresa's smile was strained, her gaze fixed on Evelyn Carter. She tentatively reached out. "Why are you dressed so lightly? You'll catch a cold."

Without hesitation, Anthony removed his suit jacket. "Here, put this on."

Evelyn stared at the offered garment but didn't take it.

Alexander narrowed his eyes. "You know each other?"

"They came to apologize for Annabelle," Evelyn said flatly.

Anthony rubbed his hands together. "Yes, yes, Annabelle was wrong..."

Alexander suddenly stepped forward, shielding Evelyn. He coldly pushed the jacket away. "I said this matter ends here."

"Alexander, we just wanted—"

"Unnecessary." His voice was icy. "Evelyn has no connection to you."

Teresa's eyes reddened. "We only care about your wellbeing..."

"My affairs are none of your concern."

Anthony suddenly chuckled. "Fine. Young people should resolve their own issues."

The atmosphere grew tense.

Evelyn broke the silence. "How is Annabelle's recovery progressing?"

"Her physical wounds have mostly healed," Anthony sighed. "But mentally..."

Alexander scoffed. "Guilt does that."

"Has she seen a psychiatrist?"

"We consulted specialists. They recommended rest." Anthony glanced uneasily at Alexander.

Evelyn nodded. "The psychiatric department at Central Hospital is excellent."

"Yes, yes."

Teresa suddenly remembered something. "Alexander, we heard you were injured?"

His Adam's apple bobbed. "Just a scratch."

"Where? Your mother is worried."

"...My leg."

"Can you walk?"

"I can."

Teresa exhaled in relief. "Good. You should keep your elders informed."

Alexander murmured a barely audible "Mm" in response.
###Chapter 319: Undercurrents

Anthony Taylor wore a gentle smile as he patted his wife's hand. "Let the young ones talk. We'd only make them uncomfortable. Uncle Dempsey mentioned wanting to see you earlier. Shall I take you to him?"

Teresa Taylor's gaze lingered on Evelyn Carter for a few seconds, hesitation flickering in her eyes. "Evelyn, we'll be back shortly."

Evelyn noticed the unspoken words trembling on Teresa's lips before they vanished.

"Alright."

As the couple walked away, Alexander Hamilton frowned. "They approached you privately?"

"Yes."

"What did they say?"

Evelyn swirled her orange juice, watching condensation slide down the glass. "Exactly what you'd expect."

Alexander's expression darkened. "Ignore them. Annabelle is their only daughter—spoiled rotten since childhood. If they bother you again, tell me immediately."

"Unnecessary." Evelyn's tone was flat. "I'm leaving the country soon. None of this matters."

Alexander stiffened. "You—"

Evelyn took a deliberate step back, eyes sharp with caution.

He chuckled dryly. "That defensive?"

"Precautionary measures."

"..."

"How was your quality time with the skeletons last time?"

Alexander's knuckles whitened, his voice rough. "What do you think?"

"I heard they remained perfectly still—not even a speck of dust disturbed." Evelyn arched a brow. "How... gentlemanly of you."

His eyes narrowed. "Don't pull that stunt again."

"Why not?"

"Do you want to be a widow?"

"I'll soon be free." A faint smile touched her lips. "They say Western culture is quite... liberal. If I feel inclined—"

"Trying to provoke me?" Alexander cut in.

"You overestimate your importance."

He smirked coldly. "Believe what you want. Just remember to protect yourself."

Evelyn blinked in surprise.

"Miss Carter—"

A flustered maid rushed over—the same one who'd earlier helped Vivian Dempsey adjust her gown.

"Here." Evelyn stood.

The maid wrung her hands. "Miss Carter, come quickly! Something's happened to Miss Vivian—"

"Another argument with Uncle Dempsey?"

"Worse!" The maid stamped her foot. "Hurry!"

Evelyn moved instantly.

Alexander stepped forward, but the maid blocked him. "Mr. Hamilton, it's better if you don't."

Evelyn glanced back. "Vivian's furious. Your presence would escalate things."

Understanding dawned. "Call me if needed."

"Mm."

The maid tugged Evelyn's sleeve. "Quickly! There's no time!"
###Chapter 320: Nightmare in the Dark

The bamboo forest rustled with an eerie whisper.

Evelyn Carter was dragged through the corridor by a maid, her high heels clicking frantically against the stone pavement.

"Where are you taking me?"

The maid didn’t answer, only tightening her grip on Evelyn’s wrist.

At the edge of the bamboo grove lay the abandoned old dock of the Dempsey family. The briny sea wind slapped against Evelyn’s face.

She yanked her hand free and turned to run.

"Ah—"

A sharp pain pierced the back of her neck.

Staggering, she collapsed to the ground as her vision blurred.

…

The pungent stench of fish invaded her nostrils.

Evelyn struggled to open her eyes, finding her hands bound behind her back with coarse rope, her delicate wrists already raw and bleeding.

In the dimly lit cabin, two men were murmuring.

"Have you lost your mind? Kidnapping someone from the Hamiltons!"

"Who cares?" Simon Stapleton crushed his cigarette underfoot. "I’ve got nothing left to lose."

The ember traced a crimson arc in the darkness.

Evelyn held her breath, nails digging into her palms.

"Alexander will find us soon," Peter Harrison warned in a hushed voice. "We should—"

"I’m counting on it!" Simon suddenly roared, kicking over a nearby oil drum. "See that? Twenty barrels of gasoline!"

Thick liquid seeped through the cracks in the deck.

A chill ran down Evelyn’s spine.

"You—" Peter’s voice trembled. "You’re planning to die together?"

Simon threw his head back with a manic laugh. "I want Alexander to watch his beloved—"

BANG!

The cabin door burst open with a violent crash.

Blinding floodlights flooded the space.

"Police! Freeze!"

Simon’s face twisted. He snatched up a machete and lunged at Evelyn.

"Stay back! Or I’ll—"

BANG!

A gunshot split the night.

Clutching his shoulder, Simon dropped to his knees. The machete clattered at Evelyn’s feet.

"Evelyn!"

The familiar voice made her eyes well up instantly.

Alexander Hamilton charged in, his suit stained with blood. He tore off the ropes and pulled her into a crushing embrace.

"It’s over now. You’re safe..."

Shivering in his arms, Evelyn suddenly caught sight of Simon’s grotesque smile.

"Look out!"

With his last ounce of strength, Simon pressed the detonator.

BOOM—

A towering inferno swallowed the entire dock.
###Chapter 321: You Taught Him?

The cramped cabin reeked of fish.

"Achoo—"

Evelyn sneezed from the overpowering stench.

The sound alerted the two men outside. The glow of a cigarette flickered as footsteps approached.

Blinding white light suddenly flooded in.

Evelyn instinctively squeezed her eyes shut.

"Awake?"

Simon crouched before her, his smile chilling. "Definitely prettier than Annabelle."

Gritting through the discomfort, Evelyn slowly opened her eyes.

The dilapidated cabin was cluttered with fishing gear. The stagnant water beneath her emitted a putrid odor. Her dress clung damply to her legs.

A frigid gust of wind pierced through her.

"Ah!"

A searing cigarette tip pressed into her neck.

Simon withdrew his hand with a vicious grin. "Even the great Dr. Carter feels pain? Always acted so high and mighty in school. Look at you now."

The burn made Evelyn gasp.

Her gaze shifted to Peter Harrison.

The man stood immaculate in his tailored suit, his hair perfectly groomed—utterly out of place in this filthy environment.

While Simon—

Grime-streaked T-shirt, mud-splattered jeans, even the cigarette between his fingers was coated in ash.

"What're you staring at?" Simon suddenly grabbed her chin. "Think I'm disgusting?"

Evelyn smirked. "You're not worth the effort."

"Looking to die?" Simon's face twisted. "I'll toss you to the sharks right now!"

"You think Alexander won't trace it back?" Evelyn turned to Peter. "Is ruining your future for trash like him worth it?"

Peter frowned deeply. "I had no part in this."

"Really?"

"Evelyn, I swear—"

"Peter!" Simon roared. "Who swore we'd be brothers for life? Who taught me to climb using women? Now you're cutting ties?!"

Evelyn's pupils constricted. "You taught him?"

Peter's expression darkened.

"How long have you known each other?" Her voice trembled. "Were you involved in what happened to Vivian too?!"
###Chapter 322: Can't You Use Your Brain?

Simon Stapleton doubled over with laughter, slapping Peter Harrison's shoulder hard. "Evelyn, finally seeing through your dear brother's true colors? If he weren't so plain-looking, he'd have made his move on you himself."

Evelyn Carter felt a tightness in her chest.

Beyond shock, it was a moment of painful clarity.

She'd always sensed something off about Peter.

Memories flashed through her mind like a revolving lantern. She'd assumed he'd merely picked up some dirty tricks from Simon. Never imagined he was the mastermind—even Vivian Dempsey's heartbreak in high school traced back to him.

"Just answer me one thing," Evelyn's voice trembled. "Did you orchestrate what happened to Vivian?"

Peter remained silent.

Simon blew smoke rings, smirking. "Evelyn, you're so dense. Peter showered you with attention in high school, and you ignored him. Yet when I used his methods on Vivian, she fell for it instantly."

Evelyn clenched her fists. "You two were in this together?"

"Not exactly." Simon flicked ash. "But he did inspire me. Helped me secure that recommendation to Hudson University."

Peter's hands subtly tightened into fists.

The slight movement didn't escape Evelyn—it only deepened her disgust.

"You hurt Vivian for a college spot. Then what was Peter's angle with me? He was two grades above us."

Simon scoffed. "The math competition, obviously! His senior year, winning could've gotten him into an elite school. But the faculty chose you—a mere freshman."

The floodgates of memory burst open.

She had represented their school in a math competition freshman year.

So that was it.

Evelyn let out a low, bitter laugh. "My apologies, Peter. Seems I was born without a romantic bone in my body."

Peter's tense posture suddenly relaxed. "No matter. Senior year didn't work out, but there's always now."

"You think that's possible?"

"You're desperate to break free from Alexander Hamilton." Peter met her gaze squarely. "Since you've seen through me, I'll drop the act. Though I must say, Evelyn, you're sharper than I expected."

"Don't flatter me." Her voice was ice. "I know the kidnapping was your solo project, Simon."

Peter's lips curled in approval.

Simon crushed his cigarette violently. "You still trust him? He's a damn fox!"

"Simon," Evelyn sighed. "Use your brain for once. Kidnapping me from the Dempseys—do you really think Alexander would let it slide? That the Dempseys wouldn't come after you? Every security camera along the way, every witness—even that maid you bribed. You think money will keep her silent when the Dempseys can make her talk?"
###Chapter 323 Alexander Obeys Your Every Word

Simon Stapleton abruptly stood up, his chair screeching across the floor.

His face twisted with fury, eyes burning like flames.

"Every piece of evidence is against you—surveillance footage, fingerprints, call logs. If anything happens to me, Alexander Hamilton and the Dempseys will hunt you to the ends of the earth." Evelyn Carter's voice was ice-cold. "Uncle Dempsey despises you. He won't show mercy this time."

Simon let out a chilling laugh. "Then we'll die together! What can the Dempseys do to me?"

"Do you really want to die?"

His smile froze.

"If the loan sharks wanted you dead, they could've done it easily. Why go through the trouble of kidnapping me?" Evelyn met his gaze unflinchingly. "You still want to live, don't you?"

Simon burst into hysterical laughter. "Now I understand why Alexander chose you. That idiot Annabelle could never compare."

"So, what's your choice?" Evelyn raised her bound wrists slightly. "Throw me into the ocean now and face the Dempseys' wrath, or untie me. I might consider helping you."

Peter Harrison had quietly moved closer, reaching for Evelyn's ropes. "The Dempseys have no quarrel with me. As for Alexander, if you testify that I wasn't involved—"

Simon shoved him violently. "You think you can walk away?!"

"I've helped you plenty." Peter calmly adjusted his cuffs. "With Vivian Dempsey, with Natalie Stapleton—haven't you benefited enough?"

A brutal punch landed on Peter's face.

"You bastard!" Simon grabbed his collar. "You think Alexander will spare you? You touched his woman—he'll kill you sooner or later!"

Peter wiped blood from his lip, his eyes darkening. "Maybe before. But now, he won't lay a hand on me in front of Evelyn."

"Ha! You think she still cares about you?"

"Whether she does or not doesn't matter." Peter smirked. "What matters is Alexander doesn't want her to see his violent side. If he hurts me, he'll lose her forever."

Simon's expression grew uglier. "I see... No wonder you dared to mess with Alexander's woman! But what about me? I'm backed into a corner! If I hadn't kidnapped her, those loan sharks would've killed me!"

"I warned you not to borrow from them." Peter flexed his injured jaw.

"Bullshit!" Simon screamed hysterically. "Lora wanted designer bags, fine dining—how else was I supposed to impress her? This was all Alexander's trap! And you—"

He pointed a trembling finger at Evelyn, veins bulging in his eyes. "Alexander obeys your every word! You're the mastermind behind all this!"
###Chapter 324: Mutual Destruction

"It was me." Evelyn Carter met Simon Stapleton's bloodshot eyes without flinching. "You destroyed my best friend. You should've seen this coming."

Simon grabbed her throat. "Vivian deserved it!"

"Deserved what? For loving a monster like you?" Evelyn's laugh was icy. "Now you're trying to ruin Natalie. I won't let that happen."

"Natalie?" Simon released her, bursting into sudden laughter. "That idiot threw herself at me. I was just having some fun."

"She's not an idiot. She truly loved you."

Simon's grin froze.

"She thought she'd found real love, but you only wanted her family's money." Evelyn spoke each word deliberately. "Simon Stapleton, scum like you belongs in hell."

"Shut up!"

Simon yanked her hair, dragging her toward the deck. The fishing boat rocked violently as waves crashed against the hull.

"See this ocean?" He forced her head toward the black water. "If I don't make it, neither will you. When Alexander finds you, all he'll get is fish food!"

Peter Harrison rushed forward. "Calm down! Alexander's almost here—"

"Back off!" Simon shoved him away. "I've got nothing left to lose!"

Peter checked his watch. "Take her as leverage. Demand enough money to start fresh abroad. I can get you out using my assistant's passport."

Simon's eyes flickered. With a twisted smile, he hauled Evelyn back into the cabin.

"What are you—"

The stench of gasoline flooded the space. Evelyn coughed violently as the liquid soaked through her clothes.

Simon strode out. The sound of splashing liquid followed. Then the cabin door slammed shut with a final thud.

"You're insane!" Peter's muffled voice came through the walls.

"This'll make Alexander pay up fast." Simon's tone was unhinged. "With multiple boats burning, he'll never know which one she's on. One delay, and he collects ashes!"

WHOOSH—

Flames engulfed the vessel instantly. Thick smoke billowed as scorching heat rolled through the cabin.

Evelyn curled in a corner, watching fire lick across every surface. Each breath seared her lungs like swallowing molten blades.

Through the inferno, she almost saw Alexander's desperate face.
###Chapter 325: Annabelle's Appearance

Flames licked hungrily at the wooden cabin walls, crackling with violent intensity.

Thick smoke billowed into the confined space, blurring Evelyn Carter's vision. She coughed violently, her throat raw as if scraped by sandpaper.

The ropes binding her wrists dug deeper, breaking skin.

"Evelyn—"

Vivian Dempsey's voice pierced through the suffocating haze.

"Terry! Answer me!"

Anthony Taylor's cry trembled with desperation.

Evelyn dragged herself to the cabin door, slamming her shoulder against it. The entire ship shuddered from the impact.

"How do we search all these boats?" Anthony's voice cracked. "Terry..."

Vivian's tone turned razor-sharp. "Alexander Hamilton, was the wire transfer completed?"

"It was."

Alexander's reply could have frozen hell itself.

"Then why did Simon— damn it! He blocked my number!"

Anthony's sobs came in broken gasps. "Alexander, think of something—"

"Dad, don't panic." A soft female voice suddenly interjected. "The fire department is almost here."

Evelyn froze.

That voice... Annabelle?

Wasn't she supposed to be hospitalized?

"Too slow." Alexander's voice held finality. "I'm going in."

"I'll come with you!"

"Unnecessary."

"I know you hate me." Annabelle's voice quivered. "But extra hands mean better odds. If Dr. Carter is hurt—"

"..."

Vivian cut in sharply. "I'll take the left side, Alexander the right. Miss Taylor, cover the central area."

"Understood." Annabelle responded without hesitation. "I won't hold back."

Anthony's anguished wails echoed in the distance.

Evelyn threw her weight against the door again, her hoarse cries barely audible.

Then—footsteps halted outside.

"Dr. Carter?"

Evelyn mustered a guttural response.

The door creaked open a sliver.

Annabelle's face appeared in the gap. Clad in a dark trench coat, her expression was unreadable.
###Chapter 326 Life Hanging by a Thread

Evelyn's fingers scraped against the deck, leaving streaks of blood.

She opened her mouth, but no sound came out.

Annabelle crouched before her, eyes tracing the ropes binding her wrists and ankles. "So you're tied up."

"Annabelle—"

Alexander's voice grew closer.

Evelyn strained every muscle to inch toward the cabin door.

A hand clamped down on her shoulder.

She looked up into Annabelle's eyes—cold and venomous.

Bang!

The cabin door slammed shut.

The click of the lock echoed sharply.

"Did you find her?"

"Don't open it!" Annabelle's voice trembled with false tears. "It's full of fire inside. Dr. Carter isn't there—"

The deck vibrated.

Alexander had boarded the ship.

"Are you sure?"

"I saw it myself. The cabin's empty." Annabelle spoke rapidly. "The flames are spreading. We need to hurry—"

Vivian's footsteps approached. "Any sign of her?"

"Nothing." Annabelle's tone was final. "Let's check the other side."

A heavy silence followed.

"Alexander?" Annabelle gasped suddenly. "That boat! I heard something!"

Footsteps scattered into the distance.

Evelyn stared at the cabin ceiling.

Flames licked at the beams above.

The realization struck her.

Simon was never the only one behind this kidnapping.

Smoke filled her lungs.

Her consciousness wavered.

A final thought flickered—

Even quails can peck.
###Chapter 327: Between Life and Death

Boom—

A deafening explosion tore through the air.

"Evelyn!!"

Who was calling her?

"Alexander, are you insane?! The fire's too intense—you'll die if you go back in!"

"Get out of my way!"

She felt herself lifted by the thick smoke, light as a feather. Strong arms wrapped around her, the familiar scent of pine mingling with the acrid smell of burning filling her nostrils.

A biting chill jolted her awake.

Her eyes fluttered open to blinding white. The sterile scent of disinfectant told her she was in a hospital.

"Evelyn!"

Vivian Dempsey rushed to the bedside, her eyes swollen like peaches. "You scared me to death! Do you have any idea?!"

She tried to speak, but her throat burned as if sliced by knives.

Vivian immediately pressed her hand down. "Don't talk! The doctor said your airways are severely damaged." She fumbled around frantically. "I brought warm water and glucose for you..."

The sound of hurried footsteps echoed outside.

The room was suddenly packed.

Evelyn's gaze swept over each face.

Anthony Taylor stood there, guilt-ridden. Olivia Lightfoot paced anxiously. Natalie Stapleton sobbed uncontrollably. "Evelyn, it's all my fault..."

She shook her head gently.

Vivian spoke for her. "Simon Stapleton is a madman. Who could've guessed he'd set the fire? My dad's already investigating who lured you to the backyard."

"My father arranged for the best pulmonologist," Natalie choked out. "You have to get better."

Her eyes traveled past the crowd.

Alexander Hamilton stood at the front, his suit charred and tattered. His exposed arms bore gruesome burns, his right cheek blackened.

Annabelle Taylor hid behind him, her clothes merely dusted with ash. "Alexander nearly died saving you."

Evelyn smirked coldly.

"His throat is injured too," Annabelle continued, "but he insisted on staying with you."

Alexander's Adam's apple bobbed, his voice hoarse. "Does it hurt?"

Vivian cut in. "She can't speak right now. Go treat your wounds first—they're practically cooked."

He didn't move.

His scorching gaze remained locked on her.
###Chapter 328: Questions for Alexander

Evelyn's gaze lingered on Alexander's face before shifting to Annabelle.

Annabelle squirmed under her scrutiny. "I'm glad you're okay, Dr. Carter," she said hastily. "I...I'm not feeling well..."

Anthony Taylor immediately supported her. "I told you not to go, but you wouldn't listen."

"Someone had to represent our family at Uncle Dempsey's birthday banquet," Annabelle murmured. "I should share the responsibilities."

Anthony patted her hand approvingly. "You've matured."

"I was too selfish before. Because of me, Alexander and Dr. Carter divorced, and you had to worry..."

"Let's not dwell on the past. This time Alexander saved Dr. Carter. Maybe there's still hope for them."

Annabelle lowered her lashes. "If they reconcile, Grandma Hamilton can rest in peace."

"Go check on your mother."

"Okay."

Vivian Dempsey leaned close to Evelyn, whispering, "Annabelle was terrified by Grandma Hamilton's ghost. She even helped search for you today."

Evelyn's eyes flickered.

"Really," Vivian insisted earnestly. "Grandma Hamilton's spirit is watching over you."

Evelyn's lashes trembled slightly.

"Alexander nearly got himself killed looking for you," Vivian continued. "The fire was raging, but he searched every boat. His back was burned when he found you."

Evelyn's lips moved with difficulty.

"What?" Vivian asked.

"She wants her phone," Alexander said.

"Yours was destroyed in the fire." Vivian frowned. "Do you need to contact your parents?"

Alexander handed over his own phone. "She needs to type."

With shaking fingers, Evelyn typed:
[Do my parents know?]

"We didn't tell them," Vivian said quickly. "We didn't want them to worry."

Evelyn exhaled in relief.

"But your injuries..." Vivian hesitated. "Your plans to go abroad might need to be postponed."

Evelyn closed her eyes briefly in understanding.

[You should all go rest.]

"No way!" Vivian refused flatly. "You're seriously hurt—"

[I need to talk to Alexander.]

Vivian caught on. "Want me to leave?"

At Evelyn's nod, she stood. "I'll be right outside." Turning to Anthony, she added, "Uncle, let me walk you out."

The room finally quieted.

Alexander bent closer. "What do you want to ask?"

Evelyn typed slowly:
[Peter told you?]

Alexander's eyes flickered. "Yes."

A bitter smile touched her lips.

Of course.

[What did he want in return?]

"He wouldn't dare." Alexander's voice turned icy. "He crossed a line this time. All he wants now is to save himself."
###Chapter 329: Kicking Me Out Again?

Evelyn Carter leaned against the hospital bed, her fingers lightly tapping the phone screen.

Peter Harrison had truly outsmarted himself this time. Despite all his scheming, he never expected Simon Stapleton to go this far. Now he'd offended both the Hamiltons and her—he must be wishing the ground would swallow him whole.

"Still feeling unwell?" Alexander Hamilton sat beside the bed, reaching to check her forehead.

Evelyn instinctively flinched away.

"I just washed my hands." He withdrew, his voice hoarse. "They're clean."

She pressed her lips together and typed: [I want to sit up.]

Alexander moved to the foot of the bed and cranked the handle. The bed gradually elevated, adjusting her into a semi-seated position.

"Is this angle okay?"

She nodded.

"Let me know if you need anything."

[Don’t tell my parents.]

"The Dempseys have been informed. This won’t spread further." He paused. "But this time, a simple 'thank you' won’t cut it."

He rolled up his sleeve, revealing the bandaged wound.

[Ask Vivian to stay with me.]

Alexander arched a brow. "Kicking me out again?"

[Your injury needs treatment.]

After a brief silence, he stood. "Fine. I’ll call her."

When Vivian Dempsey burst in, she was still ranting into her phone.

"My dad caught that maid!" She plopped down angrily. "For just five thousand bucks, she helped Simon hurt you!"

Evelyn patted the space beside her.

Vivian shook her head. "I’ll stay here—don’t want to bump your wounds." She leaned closer, lowering her voice. "What were you whispering about with Alexander? Don’t tell me you’re rekindling old flames?"

Evelyn gave a resigned smile.

She decided to keep Peter’s involvement from Vivian for now. Knowing her friend’s temper, she’d sabotage Peter’s project without hesitation if she learned the truth.

[Thank Uncle Dempsey for me.]

"This is all my fault." Vivian tugged at her hair in frustration. "If I hadn’t asked you to come, none of this would’ve—"

Evelyn squeezed her hand and shook her head.

"That bastard Simon!" Vivian seethed. "Too cowardly to confront Alexander, too weak to bully Natalie, so he targets you instead!"

[Don’t act rashly.]

"I know my limits." Vivian’s eyes suddenly lit up. "But every cloud has a silver lining—Dad promised to stop forcing me on blind dates!"

Evelyn smiled and nodded: [Just be yourself.]

"But what about you?" Vivian frowned. "Your plans to study abroad..."

[I’m going.] Evelyn typed firmly.
###Chapter 330: Keep Pretending

"How are you getting to the hospital now?"

[Don’t let my parents know. They’ll worry.]

"Then how do you want to handle this? What can I do to help?"

Evelyn Carter’s fingers hovered over her phone screen. After a moment’s hesitation, she lowered her hand.

She pointed at Vivian Dempsey’s phone.

"Use mine?"

Evelyn gave a slight nod.

Vivian handed it over without hesitation. "Here."

Evelyn quickly typed a line of text and turned the screen toward her.

Vivian studied it for a moment before nodding firmly. "Alright, we’ll do it that way. But it’ll take a few days to prepare."

A knock sounded at the door.

Vivian tensed and turned. "Who is it?"

"Terry, I couldn’t stop worrying. I had to come see you."

It was Teresa Taylor’s voice.

Vivian lowered her voice. "Annabelle’s mom. Do you want to see her?"

Evelyn gave a small nod.

Vivian walked over and opened the door.

Teresa was still in her wheelchair, but this time, Annabelle was the one pushing it.

Teresa’s eyes were red-rimmed, and Annabelle leaned down to dab at her tears with a tissue. "Mom, stop crying. Dr. Carter is awake now."

Teresa clutched her daughter’s hand. "That’s good. That’s so good."

Vivian crossed her arms, her gaze shifting between the two. "What do you want?"

Annabelle offered a placating smile. "My mom has been worried sick about Dr. Carter. She insisted on coming. Miss Dempsey, just let her say a few words. We won’t stay long."

Vivian didn’t budge. She peered into the hallway. "Alexander Hamilton, why are you hiding out there?"

"Hmm?"

Alexander stood.

"Get in here."

He raised an eyebrow. "Since when are you so friendly with me?"

Vivian scoffed. "Consider it a one-hour privilege for saving Evelyn this time. But I’ve learned my lesson. Your wife and mother-in-law are both fragile. If something happens in this room, I won’t take the blame."

Teresa winced. "You’re Dr. Carter’s close friend, aren’t you?"

"That’s right. We grew up together—closer than sisters. Got a problem with that?"

"No, I’m just glad Dr. Carter has someone like you."

Vivian frowned at Alexander. "What’s your mother-in-law trying to say?"

Alexander looked equally confused. "Aunt Teresa, did you know Evelyn before?"

"I..." Teresa’s tears spilled over. She choked back a sob. "No, I just thought it was such a coincidence that Dr. Carter and Annabelle share the same name. Seeing her hurt breaks my heart."

Vivian smirked coldly. "You’re overthinking it, ma’am. Evelyn and your daughter are worlds apart. Don’t even compare them."

Teresa bowed her head. "Annabelle was spoiled rotten. She’s made so many mistakes. I apologize on her behalf."

"Don’t. I don’t deserve it. Besides, she wronged Evelyn, not me."

"You’re right." Teresa’s voice softened. "Lately, Annabelle has been having nightmares. Her mental state fluctuates. It’s karma. She truly regrets everything now. Last night, when she heard Dr. Carter was missing, she insisted on searching—we couldn’t stop her..."

Vivian side-eyed Annabelle.

Her head was bowed, tears welling in her eyes.
###Chapter 331: The Blood-Tied Dilemma

She waved her hand impatiently. "At least she still has some conscience this time."

"Can I speak with Dr. Carter alone?"

Vivian Dempsey crossed her arms. "Make it quick. Don't disturb Evelyn's rest."

"Understood."

Annabelle Taylor wheeled herself to the hospital bed.

Teresa Taylor's eyes welled up the moment she saw Evelyn lying pale and weak. Trembling, she grasped Evelyn's hand. "My child, you've suffered so much."

Evelyn's gaze flickered between Teresa and Annabelle.

Alexander Hamilton stepped closer but maintained a respectful distance.

Evelyn handed his phone back.

He took it. "Done using it?"

She shook Vivian's phone instead.

Alexander was silent for a moment. "I'll have Emily bring you a new one."

Teresa suddenly turned. "Annabelle."

"Yes, Mom?"

"Give me your hand."

She placed Annabelle's hand over Evelyn's, clasping them tightly. "Even your names are so similar—it's fate. From now on, you must treat Dr. Carter as your own sister. Do you understand?"

Annabelle nodded obediently. "I will."

"Dr. Carter," Teresa pleaded, "Annabelle and Alexander's engagement will be called off. They'll just be siblings now. You and Alexander should focus on your marriage. I only want you both to be happy—"

Evelyn yanked her hand away.

Teresa froze. "You still resent us?"

Evelyn locked eyes with Annabelle, her lips curling into a cold smile.

Annabelle's gaze wavered, but she forced a smile. "Mom, Dr. Carter has every right to be angry. I'll prove myself through actions."

"Good girl." Teresa nodded in relief. "My greatest wish in life has come true. But... a mother's love is torn between her children."

"Mom, what do you mean?"

"Remember, Dr. Carter is your sister now. Even if she and Alexander have conflicts, you must stand by her side."

Annabelle nodded solemnly. "I'll remember."

Vivian suddenly let out a derisive laugh. "Spare us the sisterly act. Evelyn already has a real sister—she doesn't need this fake affection. Besides, she's already divorced Alexander. Isn't this arrangement a bit presumptuous?"
###Chapter 332: Simon's Whereabouts

Teresa Taylor forced a smile. "Divorces always have their reasons. Back then it was because of Annabelle... but let's not dwell on painful memories. Now that the misunderstanding is cleared up, reconciliation isn't impossible."

"That's not—"

Annabelle suddenly interrupted. "Miss Dempsey, shouldn't Evelyn and Alexander handle their own affairs? You're her friend, but ultimately not involved. If they truly love each other, your interference will only delay them."

Vivian Dempsey fell silent.

Earlier, Evelyn had deliberately sent her away to speak with Alexander alone.

She had no rebuttal.

Vivian stammered, "But this has nothing to do with you or your mother, does it? Mind your own business."

"Fine," Annabelle nodded meekly. "We'll stay out of it. Let Evelyn and Alexander resolve things themselves."

Vivian scoffed but softened her tone. "That's more like it."

"We've found Simon."

Alexander pocketed his phone, his expression grim. "Evelyn, stay with Vivian. I'll deal with him."

Vivian shot to her feet. "Where?"

Alexander hesitated, glancing at Evelyn. "Hamilton Group's underground garage."

"Ha! Alexander, if you don't roast him alive this time, I'll lose all respect for you!"

Alexander replied with two words: "Just wait."

He approached the bed, gripping Evelyn's hand over the blanket. "I'll be back soon."

To Vivian, he added, "Take care of Evelyn."

"Whether you come back or not doesn't matter—just make sure Simon ends up as barbecue! Extra cumin, please!"

A cold smirk tugged at Alexander's lips. "I'll send photos."

He nodded at Teresa. "Mrs. Taylor, I'll take my leave."

"Alexander, don't act rashly. Leave it to the police."

"I know my limits."

With that, he left.

Vivian snorted, turning to Evelyn. "Focus on recovering. If Simon's in Alexander's hands, he'll wish he were dead."

Evelyn nodded absently.

Her gaze remained fixed on Annabelle.

When Alexander departed, Annabelle's eyes followed him until he disappeared through the door, only then reluctantly looking away.

She turned—and met Evelyn's probing stare.

Annabelle flustered. "Dr. Carter, do you need anything?"

Teresa chimed in, "Yes, let Annabelle help. Miss Dempsey should rest."

Evelyn averted her eyes, typing on her phone.

[Finished? Then leave.]

Teresa's eyes reddened as she turned away.

Annabelle patted her mother's shoulder reassuringly. "Dr. Carter, my mother genuinely cares about you. If we've disturbed you, we apologize."

Evelyn typed a single word: [Go.]

Teresa wiped her eyes. "Alright, we'll go. Rest well."

Annabelle wheeled her chair toward the door. "Dr. Carter, we'll leave now."

Evelyn turned her head away, ignoring them.

Vivian shut the door and returned to the bedside. "That homewrecker's mother seems to genuinely see you as a daughter. Her concern didn't seem fake."

Evelyn typed again.

"And Annabelle... she's like a different person now. She risked everything to save you."

[She found me first.]

Vivian's eyes widened. "What? I thought it was Alexander..."

[Then she pushed me back into hell.]
###Chapter 333: Going Abroad

Sunlight streamed through the hospital window as Vivian Dempsey sat by the bed, peeling an apple.

"Open up." She held out a small piece to Evelyn Carter. "I peeled this myself. You have to eat it all."

Evelyn obediently opened her mouth. The sweetness of the apple spread across her tongue.

The TV played a news segment: Police have identified a suspect in the dockyard arson case. Sources say the individual incurred massive debts from failed investments...

Vivian rolled her eyes. "They're really glossing over the details. Won't even mention a name."

She leaned closer to Evelyn, lowering her voice. "My dad asked around. Simon Stapleton has vanished without a trace."

Evelyn's fingers tapped lightly on her phone: Alexander Hamilton?

"Don't even ask," Vivian scoffed. "Hamilton Group's headquarters is business as usual. Cars come and go from the underground garage every day. But..." Her voice dropped further. "I heard there's security posted at an abandoned freezer warehouse on the outskirts of town."

Evelyn's hand stilled.

"Don't overthink it." Vivian patted her shoulder. "Focus on recovering first. Oh, I already booked our flights."

Evelyn typed quickly: The sooner, the better.

Three days later, Heathrow Airport, London.

"Welcome to England!" A blue-eyed blonde woman greeted them warmly. "I'm Laura, head of the hospital's international exchange program."

Vivian conversed fluently in English, occasionally translating for Evelyn.

During the hospital tour, Laura pointed to a red phone booth outside the window. "That's our landmark. All new doctors take photos there."

Evelyn smiled and nodded.

"Your office is on the fifth floor," Laura gestured. "Great view of the Thames."

As they exited the hospital, Vivian linked arms with Evelyn, excited. "Let's hit Chinatown for a proper meal, then go apartment hunting!"

The setting sun stretched their shadows long across the pavement. Evelyn gazed at the foreign sky and exhaled softly.
###Chapter 334: Imaginary Friends?

"Britain is a culinary wasteland. I'm going insane." Vivian Dempsey slumped in the café chair, stirring her milk tea listlessly. "I should've packed all the hotpot spices from home."

Evelyn Carter typed on her phone: [There's a Sichuan restaurant near the hospital.]

"Don't even mention it." Vivian rolled her eyes. "They made mapo tofu sweet. That's an insult to Sichuan cuisine."

[What if we buy ingredients and cook ourselves?]

Vivian sat up abruptly. "Your throat hasn't healed! You can't cook yet."

Evelyn shook her head gently and typed: [The doctor said normal activities are fine. I just can't speak temporarily.]

"Really?" Vivian's eyes lit up before dimming again. "But finding an apartment is such a hassle. Dad already offered his villa—"

Evelyn shook her head firmly.

She wouldn't impose on the Dempseys further. Besides, their villa was an hour's commute from the hospital.

Vivian sighed. "Knew I couldn't change your mind."

A phone rang.

Vivian checked the caller ID and winked. "It's Dr. Wilson."

Evelyn's brow furrowed.

"Hey Greg," Vivian answered. "What? Seriously...?"

She suddenly covered the receiver. "Gregory says his friend has a vacant villa near the hospital. He's offering it to us."

Evelyn's frown deepened.

Friend?

Surely not...

"It's legit," Vivian read her thoughts. "I know the guy—Greg's senior from med school who moved back home last year."

Seeing Evelyn's hesitation, Vivian spoke into the phone. "Send the address. We're coming now!"

Hanging up, she pulled Evelyn up. "Stop overthinking. Let's see it first. He said it's a cottage with a garden!"

Twenty minutes later, they stood before a red-brick house.

The location was perfect—ten minutes from the hospital yet secluded from main roads.

Vivian retrieved a key from the mailbox. The lock clicked open.

No musty smell greeted them.

Instead, lavender wafted through spotless floors—clearly maintained regularly.

"This is amazing!" Vivian twirled like a child. "Look at this sofa! The coffee table! And—"

She froze.

Evelyn followed her gaze.

Centered on the living room wall hung an enormous oil painting.

A girl's back was turned, walking down a path strewn with plane tree leaves. Golden sunlight filtered through branches, dappling her silhouette.
###Chapter 335: The Secret in the Oil Painting

Vivian Dempsey leaned closer to the oil painting, her fingertip lightly brushing the canvas.

"This streetlamp..." She frowned in thought. "Why does it look so much like the one behind the medical school's lab building?"

Evelyn Carter's fingers tightened slightly.

She lowered her lashes, avoiding the smiling gaze of the girl in the painting.

"Am I remembering wrong?" Vivian scratched her head. "The last time I went to the medical school was three years ago."

Evelyn pressed her lips together and shook her head.

"Okay." Vivian shrugged. "Maybe all European-style streetlamps look the same."

Evelyn pointed at her phone.

"Oh, right!" Vivian smacked her forehead. "Your parents must be worried sick."

The moment the video call connected, three anxious faces filled the screen.

"Sis! You scared us to death!" Emily Anderson's eyes were red-rimmed.

Grace Anderson's voice trembled. "Evelyn, why did you suddenly go abroad?"

Evelyn's throat tightened.

"Don't worry, Auntie." Vivian turned the camera toward the window. "There's a critical patient here who insisted Evelyn perform the surgery."

Andrew Anderson studied his daughter's pale face. "Why aren't you speaking?"

"She just finished an eight-hour surgery." Vivian handed her a glass of water. "Her throat's gone hoarse."

Grace wrung her hands anxiously. "What about food? Does the hospital provide meals?"

Evelyn scribbled "dorm" on a notepad.

"The hospital values Evelyn so much!" Vivian gestured dramatically. "They gave us a two-bedroom apartment with a kitchen."

Andrew nudged his wife's shoulder proudly. "See? I told you our daughter would be in demand anywhere!"

"Then why don't you show Vivian your cooking skills?" Grace suddenly laughed. "Remember when she mistook sugar for salt and dumped half a jar in the pan during her first attempt?"

Evelyn's ears burned. She grabbed a pillow and threw it at the screen.

Vivian suddenly gasped. "Wait!"

She zoomed in on the video, pointing at the painting behind Evelyn. "Uncle, Auntie, look at this streetlamp..."
###Chapter 336: Evelyn, It's Me

Emily Anderson covered her mouth, suppressing a giggle. "Mom, Evelyn is trying her best."

Anthony Taylor quickly mediated. "Evelyn never liked cooking as a child. The fact that she's trying now is already progress. Besides, she's so busy with work—when would she have time to practice?"

Listening to her family's comforting words, Evelyn Carter felt the tension in her shoulders ease slightly.

Vivian Dempsey thumped her chest confidently. "Don't worry, Auntie! I have an iron stomach. I could eat three bowls of Evelyn's cooking!"

"Vivian, could you send me Evelyn's new address? I just learned how to use navigation apps and want to see where she's living now."

Vivian glanced at Evelyn for permission before nodding. "Of course, Auntie. I'll send it to you right away."

"Oh, and remember to get a local SIM card soon. You can't keep relying on Vivian to contact Evelyn every time."

"Got it. We'll take care of it when we go out later."

After hanging up, Vivian exhaled in relief. "Feel better now?"

Evelyn gave a small nod.

Suddenly, the phone rang again.

"It's my dad," Vivian said, her expression darkening as she answered. "What?! Okay, I'll book a flight immediately."

Evelyn shot her a questioning look.

Vivian's face paled. "My grandmother fell. She's in the hospital now."

Evelyn immediately pushed her toward the door.

Vivian hesitated. "But you just got here, and you don't even speak the language..."

Evelyn typed rapidly on her phone: [Falls are serious for elderly patients. You need to go.]

"But you'll be alone..."

[I can take care of myself.]

Years of working in the hospital had taught Evelyn how dangerous falls could be for the elderly. If Vivian's father was calling now, the situation must be critical.

Vivian pulled her into a tight hug. "I'll come back as soon as things stabilize."

Evelyn nodded firmly and quickly hailed a taxi for her.

Watching her friend leave, the apartment suddenly felt oppressively quiet.

Evelyn took a deep breath and began organizing her new home. She made two trips to the supermarket, filling the fridge to bursting, then arranged the bedroom into a cozy sanctuary.

At dinner, she sighed at the charred eggs in the pan. Years of relying on hospital cafeterias and others' cooking had left her skills rusty.

Outside, a light rain began to fall.

Just as Evelyn moved to lock the door, the doorbell rang.

Startled, she tapped the door to signal her presence.

Then came that achingly familiar voice from the other side:

"Evelyn, it's me."
###Chapter 337: She Knew What It Meant

The doorbell rang while Evelyn Carter was packing her luggage.

She paused, wondering who could be visiting at this hour.

Peering through the peephole, she saw Gregory Wilson standing outside, drenched from head to toe.

Rainwater dripped steadily from his hair, forming a small puddle at his feet.

Evelyn quickly pulled the door open.

"May I come in?" His voice was hoarse.

She stepped aside, but Gregory didn’t enter immediately. Instead, he shook the water from his hair at the doorstep.

Evelyn hurried to the bathroom and grabbed a fresh towel.

"It’s new," she gestured, worried he might misunderstand.

Gregory shook his head. "No need. Do you have tissues?"

She turned to fetch a box of tissues and pointed to the sofa, inviting him to sit.

"I’m soaked. I’ll stand." He wiped his face carelessly with a tissue. "Your throat still hurts?"

Evelyn nodded.

"Did you take your medicine?"

Another nod.

Gregory glanced at the floor. "Sorry for making a mess again."

Evelyn waved her hand to say it was fine.

"You still haven’t bought a phone?" He suddenly handed her his own. "Use mine to type."

Before she could react, the phone was already in her hands.

"Passcode is 0326."

Her heartbeat quickened inexplicably as she entered the numbers.

When the screen unlocked, she secretly exhaled in relief.

It wasn’t her birthday, nor were there any traces of her in his phone.

The number 0326 held no meaning for her.

The wallpaper was just the default image of a blue sky with white clouds.

A man who had been in the country that morning now stood before her in the middle of the night, drenched from the English rain.

She wasn’t naive about what this meant.

Since her clear rejection last time, Gregory had never brought up the subject again.

But some things couldn’t be ignored just because they went unspoken.

[Why did you suddenly come to England? What about the hospital?]

Gregory leaned closer to read the screen. "I’ve worked in England before. The dean knows about this."

[When are you going back?]

He chuckled. "Am I making you uncomfortable?"

[No, I just don’t want to interfere with your work.]

"I have a place to stay. I was planning to visit properly tomorrow." He paused. "I just remembered this house has old wiring. Power outages happen during storms. I didn’t want you to be alone and scared."

Warmth bloomed in Evelyn’s chest. [Thank you.]

"For coming to see you?"

[For the house.]

When Vivian Dempsey mentioned knowing the landlord, Evelyn had been skeptical.

Especially after seeing the oil painting in the living room—her suspicions had only grown stronger.
###Chapter 338 I Just Don't Want You to Catch Cold

Gregory Wilson's eyes flickered slightly, as if deciphering her unspoken question. "You guessed it?"

She gave a slight nod.

"Technically, this house doesn't belong to me," he tapped the table with his slender fingers. "The original owners were an elderly couple who moved to Australia. I'm just a long-term tenant."

[I can share the rent.]

Gregory pondered for a moment. "Let's wait until your job stabilizes. There's no rush."

She had left in a hurry, and her wallet was indeed light.

At least until next month's payday, she wouldn't have spare funds.

[I'll pay you back later.]

"Alright."

"..."

"It's getting late. You should rest." As he stood, Evelyn Carter noticed the small carry-on suitcase.

It was so tiny it couldn't even fit a thick coat.

The temperature in London was only ten degrees, and his trench coat was already soaked through from the rain, clinging to his body.

[Did you bring a change of clothes?]

Gregory paused mid-step, glancing at the suitcase. "It was a last-minute trip. I only packed essentials."

[Are there any of your clothes here?]

His gaze suddenly grew intense.

Evelyn had always stayed in the guest bedroom, never setting foot in the master suite.

If this was his former residence...

"In the master bedroom closet."

[Have you eaten?]

"Airplane food."

That dry, tasteless excuse for a meal hardly counted.

Evelyn tightened her grip on her phone. [Go take a hot shower and change first.]

Gregory's eyes darkened abruptly.

A mix of surprise and confusion flickered through them.

She quickly added, [I just don't want you to catch cold.]

The corner of his lips quirked up, though the smile didn't reach his eyes. "I understand."

[Your health comes first.]

"Mm," he nodded. "Thank you."

[I'll make dinner. You go get settled.]

Gregory raised an eyebrow. "You can cook?"

[No promises on taste, but it'll fill you up.]

[I feel terrible making you come out in the rain so late. Consider this my thanks.]

He studied her for a long moment before finally nodding. "Alright."

In the open kitchen, Evelyn retrieved eggs and pasta from the fridge.

As the water boiled, the faint sound of running water came from the master bedroom.

So the master suite had its own bathroom.

She breathed a quiet sigh of relief.

At least they wouldn't have any awkward encounters.

When the tangy aroma of tomatoes filled the air, Gregory descended the wooden staircase.

A white turtleneck sweater softened his usual sharp edges, while black sweatpants accentuated his long legs.

"Smells amazing."

Evelyn plated the pasta and carried it to the dining table.
###Chapter 339: Are You Together Now?

Gregory Wilson raised an eyebrow slightly. "Which department in a hospital isn't constantly swamped? I always see you grabbing meals at the hospital cafeteria. Didn’t expect you to be such a good cook."

Evelyn Carter handed him a fork, the corner of her lips lifting.

Gregory stared at the brand-new fork, his brow furrowing almost imperceptibly.

He stood abruptly and walked to the kitchen, pulling open the third drawer to retrieve a pair of chopsticks.

"Still prefer these," he said as he sat back down, scanning the table. "Why only one serving?"

Evelyn’s fingers twisted together unconsciously.

Her surgeries had been back-to-back today, leaving her only enough time to scarf down two slices of bread.

"You skipped dinner?" Gregory’s voice darkened.

With quick movements, he divided the pasta into two portions and pushed one toward her. "Doctors should eat on time."

The fork was pressed back into her hand, its cool metal seeping into her palm.

A sudden ringtone shattered the silence.

"Vincent."

"Bro! Why did you suddenly fly to the UK?!"

Gregory twirled noodles around his chopsticks. "Work."

"What’s so urgent? Unless—" The voice on the other end dropped to a whisper. "Did Evelyn go with you?"

The air froze.

Evelyn’s fork hovered mid-air.

Gregory glanced at her before responding calmly, "Yes."

"Oh no, no, no..." Vincent groaned. "Alexander’s been tearing the city apart looking for her. Vivian isn’t answering her calls either. Mom and Dad said you went back to the UK, so I figured—"

"We didn’t come together."

"But are you two...?" Vincent’s voice trembled. "Are you together right now?"

Gregory picked up a mushroom. "Yes."

"It’s past midnight in London! You two—"

"Don’t overthink it."

Frantic rustling came through the phone. "Greg, please, I’m begging you—don’t let Alexander know I called you!"

Chopsticks tapped lightly against the porcelain plate.

Gregory chuckled. "That scared of him?"

"You’re both my brothers! I’m stuck in the middle here!" Vincent sounded close to tears. "I don’t even know what to call Evelyn anymore..."

"Dr. Carter is fine."

"That’s not the point!" Vincent wailed. "If you two end up fighting over her, I can’t pick sides!"
###Chapter 340: You Can Always Come to Me for Help

"Let's pretend nothing happened."

"I can turn a blind eye, but..." Gregory Wilson suddenly lowered his voice. "Hold on, I'm getting another call."

"Mm."

Alexander Hamilton set down his phone and continued eating his noodles unhurriedly.

Noticing Evelyn Carter hadn't touched her food, he gently reminded her, "Eat while it's hot."

Evelyn shook her head and pointed to her stomach.

"Afraid of gaining weight?"

[It's too late.]

"Rushing your plans to move abroad without even getting a local SIM card," Gregory set down his chopsticks. "Are you trying to avoid Alexander?"

[Yes.]

"With his connections, he'll find you eventually."

[Let him try.]

Evelyn had already braced herself for it.

Alexander had his career, his family, and that persistent shadow—Annabelle Taylor—back home.

The fire incident had finally revealed Annabelle's true nature. All that talk of repentance and change? Just an act to manipulate Alexander's sympathy.

If the flames had spread further that day, if Alexander had arrived a moment later...

Annabelle's desperate gamble had been flawless.

A "martyr" who sacrificed herself for love would forever remain Alexander's deepest regret.

And Evelyn? Just a replacement living in Annabelle's shadow.

"If you need help, I'm here."

"..."

"I've lived in England for years. I have connections." Gregory's gaze was steady. "If you want to disappear completely, I can make it happen."

His phone rang again.

Vincent Wilson's voice cracked with panic. "Greg, Alexander's already on his way to the airport!"

"Who told him?"

"It wasn't me! He went to Evelyn's hometown—"

"Got it."

"Greg, I tried my best..." Vincent sounded frantic. "Just... don't start a fight, okay?"

"Do you think we're animals?"

"Isn't that how males compete for mates?" Vincent groaned. "You're both like brothers to me. I can't pick sides—"

"The choice is Evelyn's." Gregory's tone remained calm. "Alexander can't force her."

Ding—

Another call came through.

An unknown number flashed on the screen.

Gregory chuckled. "He's here."
###Chapter 341: I Thought You Had Something to Tell Me

Gregory Wilson's lips curled into an amused smile. "He's quite resourceful. Knowing your phone is broken, he called me directly."

He shook his phone lightly. "Should I answer?"

Evelyn Carter stared at the unfamiliar number flashing on the screen and shook her head.

"Want me to hang up?"

After a brief hesitation, she gestured indifferently.

Gregory chuckled and flipped the phone face-down on the table. "Let's eat first."

The ringing pierced the quiet living room, but he ignored it, leisurely eating his noodles.

Until the sound abruptly stopped.

"Feel better now?" Gregory set down his chopsticks, his gaze intense.

Evelyn looked up, puzzled.

"Seeing Alexander Hamilton so desperate to reach you—even calling his rival—does that ease your mind a little?"

Finally, she understood his meaning.

Evelyn shook her head.

"Still not satisfied?"

Another shake.

Her relationship with Alexander was never just about simple love or hate.

Those three years of marriage were merely two compatible people sharing a life. Annabelle Taylor's appearance only made that truth clearer.

She pointed at the phone.

Gregory handed it to her.

With practiced movements, Evelyn blocked the number and returned the device.

Burning hot!

###Chapter 342 Someone Still Calls Her Mrs. Hamilton

Alexander had followed her to England?

###Chapter 344: I Came Here for You

The hospital corridor reeked of antiseptic at dawn.

###Chapter 356 Unexpected Reunion

This chance encounter was proving far more interesting than she'd anticipated.
###Chapter 357: The Confrontation Behind the Masks

###Chapter 358: Stop Calling or You're Blocked

A light drizzle drifted through London's streets.

###Chapter 359: I Brought Her Here

Alexander's fingers tightened abruptly. Condensation slid down his knuckles as his gaze sharpened toward Annabelle.

Annabelle quickly changed the subject. "Linda, where's your wedding gown? Why aren't you wearing it?"

"That bulky dress would ruin my dancing." Linda laughed, suddenly grabbing Evelyn Carter's wrist. "Let me introduce our mystery guest—"

Evelyn was yanked into the crowd's center, unprepared for the two piercing stares that locked onto her.

One scorching enough to burn through her. The other frigid as glacial ice.

"This is the Eastern beauty from my favorite oil painting! Her name is Evelyn. Isn't she more stunning than the portrait?"

Evelyn lowered her lashes.

She could feel those twin gazes dissecting her inch by inch.

"Evelyn, meet my dear friends—Jane and her fiancé Alexander." Linda beamed. "Alexander's the devoted type. He pursued Jane for ten whole years!"

Evelyn lifted her eyes, lips curving. "Congratulations."

The air turned to stone.

Annabelle's face drained of color. Alexander let out a cold laugh, switching to Mandarin. "Phone broken?"

"No."

"Then why ignore my calls?"

"I didn't want to answer."

"So you'd rather elope with Gregory Wilson?"

"Yes."

Alexander's knuckles whitened. The glass creaked ominously in his grip. "Running from me? Or running to him?"

"Which answer would you prefer?"

"Where is he?" Alexander scanned the room. "Ditched you here alone while he hides?"

"Why do you need him?"

"What do you think?"

Uncle Dempsey's warning flashed through Evelyn's mind—the maritime disaster where Alexander was the sole survivor.

Her fingers instinctively clenched the railing. "Today's meant for celebration."

Alexander's chest heaved before he finally hissed, "Engine room. Ten minutes."

Linda leaned in curiously. "What were you discussing? You all know Evelyn?"

Annabelle forced a smile. "We're... old friends."

"What a coincidence!"

"Yes..."

Alexander slammed his glass onto a passing tray. "Excuse me."

As he passed Evelyn, he paused just long enough to whisper, "Dare to skip this, and see what happens."

His silhouette vanished into the ship's shadows, leaving only shattered ice in his wake.
###Chapter 370: My Life, My Rules

The sea breeze brushed against her face as Annabelle leaned against the ship's railing, her eyes glinting. "Dr. Carter, aren't you going inside to rest?"

Linda happened to pass by and asked with concern, "Evelyn, should I call Gregory back to keep you company?"

Evelyn shook her head. The last thing she wanted was to run into him right now.

"Then enjoy the ocean view," Linda said with a smile. "There's a buffet in the dining hall, and all six cabins are open for use. I should go prepare now."

Watching Linda walk away surrounded by her bridesmaids, Evelyn turned to Annabelle, who hadn't moved. "Aren't you leaving?"

Annabelle sauntered closer but deliberately maintained distance. "Gregory Wilson brought you to such an intimate private wedding. Your relationship must be special."

Evelyn gazed at the distant horizon and didn't respond.

This wedding was unusual—no bridal gown, no elders, only close friends. She understood Gregory's intentions but chose not to acknowledge them.

"I'm the groom's friend," Annabelle suddenly said. "I handled his divorce case from his last marriage."

Evelyn arched an eyebrow. "I see."

Annabelle spun around abruptly. "Name your price."

"What?"

"Leave Alexander."

Evelyn scoffed. "I've already fled abroad. Isn't that enough?"

"If I wanted to string him along, you wouldn't even get close to him." Evelyn turned to leave. "Instead of wasting time here, go find him yourself. There are five cabins—take your pick."

Annabelle froze in place.

Without looking back, Evelyn walked toward the cabins. The six cabins lined both sides of the ship, so quiet the sound of waves was all that remained.
###Chapter 371 Alexander Must Be in There

Laughter and chatter spilled from the dressing room.

As Evelyn passed by, she glimpsed Linda through the half-open door. The bride sat before the vanity in a fiery red dress, applying lipstick while her bridesmaids giggled around her, adjusting the hem of her gown.

Five cabins lined the hallway. Four stood open.

Only the one at the far end remained tightly shut.

Evelyn paused briefly.

She walked straight to the cabin opposite the dressing room and locked the door behind her.

The space was compact but well-appointed.

A mini fridge stocked with assorted drinks sat beside a small sofa. Since she didn’t drink, Evelyn moved to the window seat instead.

Seagulls circled the ship’s wake, their wings skimming the azure waves.

The noise outside grew louder.

"Linda, your necklace is crooked!"

"Oh my god, these heels are impossible to walk in..."

Footsteps faded down the hall.

Her phone vibrated in her palm.

[Gregory: The reception’s starting. Where are you?]

She typed back: [Resting in my cabin. Not going.]

[Not feeling well?]

[Just need quiet.]

[Want me to come over?]

[No.]

The typing indicator appeared.

[I think I just saw Annabelle.]

Evelyn immediately called him.

"She introduced herself as the groom’s lawyer," Evelyn said, watching the horizon. "Does Linda know Paul was divorced?"

A soft chuckle came through the line. "Westerners are more relaxed about marriage. Second or third weddings are common here."

"That’s good."

"You’ve grown wary of men lately."

The corner of Evelyn’s mouth twitched.

Alexander. Peter Harrison. Simon Stapleton.

Even Vincent Wilson was a notorious playboy.

"Some of our peers are reliable."

"Such as?"

"Me."

Silence filled the line.

A pause.

"Yes."

"Can you tell me about it?"

"Paul’s ex-wife cheated. The child wasn’t his. Annabelle won him a favorable settlement with substantial assets."

"And the child—"
###Chapter 372: A Familiar Profile

"The baby didn't make it." Gregory Wilson's voice carried exhaustion through the phone. "As the attending physician, I testified in court. Only the mother survived."

An inexplicable tightness gripped Evelyn's chest. "No. That's all for now."

Click—

The doorknob turned abruptly.

"Who's there?" she demanded sharply.

Evelyn yanked the door open, catching only a fleeting glimpse of a retreating figure.

That profile made her freeze.

It was achingly familiar.

The same contours she saw every morning in her mirror.

Perhaps a trick of the dim lighting.

Her gaze flickered toward Alexander Hamilton's cabin—the door slightly ajar.

He should be at the wedding.

As she reentered her room, a thunderous crash shook her door.

Knocking erupted—frantic, relentless.

"Identify yourself!"

Silence.

The pounding intensified, wood groaning under the assault.

Cautiously, she cracked the door open.

A towering figure collapsed inward.

The stench of alcohol flooded her senses.

Before she could react, she was pinned against the wall. Scorching lips crushed hers with bruising force.

"Mmph—"

"Lock it..." He braced against the wall, veins bulging at his temples.

Her fingers brushed his neck—burning feverishly.

"Checked every cabin. Nothing."
"Impossible! Not on deck or in the lobby—he must be here."

Annabelle Taylor and that girl.

Alexander clamped a hand over her mouth. "Not a sound."
###Chapter 373: You're Never This Gentle

The scent of alcohol lingered in the air.

She frowned slightly.

Had he been drinking?

Alexander Hamilton's full weight pressed against her, his scorching breath grazing her neck.

Something was wrong.

She knew his alcohol tolerance well—he wouldn't be this drunk so easily.

Besides, Annabelle and that unfamiliar girl were still searching for him outside.

"What did you take?" she whispered.

He shook his head, his hair brushing her collarbone.

"Just a little wine..."

His lips nearly touched her skin, burning with unnatural heat.

Evelyn instinctively tried to pull away.

But Alexander tightened his grip on her shoulders. "I've been drugged."

Her chest constricted.

Of course.

That girl!

BANG!

###Chapter 374: Leaving an Heir Before Death

###Chapter 375 Hidden Secrets

###Chapter 376: His Scent

###Chapter 377 The Truth Emerges

###Chapter 380 None of Your Business.

Evelyn turned toward the balcony, settling the dog on a cushion. "That's his business. Why tell me?"
###Chapter 382: That's Her Mother, Not Yours

Gregory Wilson's fingers tapped lightly on the armrest. "He never contacted you?"

Evelyn Carter cradled the white puppy in her lap, fingers sinking into its fluffy fur. "It's been over between us for a long time."

"I thought he'd at least give you closure."

A sliver of sunlight slipped through the curtains, painting a thin golden line on the floor. Evelyn stared at it absently.

"Forget it." Gregory stood, his white coat swaying slightly. "I shouldn't have meddled."

"Dr. Wilson." Evelyn looked up. "Every time you confess your feelings, I distance myself from you."

His lips twisted into a bitter smile. "I know."

"Because I don't know how to respond. Not giving false hope might be the kindest thing."

"I understand." He walked toward the door, his posture rigid. "We'll discuss your weekend move later."

She didn't realize those words held another meaning.

The call came unexpectedly during lunch break.

"Evelyn!" Vivian Dempsey's voice crackled with excitement. "I just saw Alexander Hamilton! Right outside your parents' place!"

Evelyn's fingers dug into her palm. "What was he doing there?"

"He carried bags upstairs and stayed over an hour before leaving—with everything still packed!" Vivian gloated. "Your parents totally shut him down!"

Evelyn's shoulders relaxed slightly. "Are Mom and Dad okay?"

"Perfectly fine! Your sister even served me fruit." Vivian dropped her voice. "Oh, and guess what? That homewrecker Annabelle's mom is dying!"

Evelyn shot up, knocking over her water glass.

"What did you say?"

"That sickly woman—doctors say she won't last this time." Vivian sneered. "Like mother, like daughter. Serves them right!"

Evelyn's hands trembled. "Vivian, I have to go."

"Wait, why the—"

She hung up and immediately dialed Alexander.

After endless rings, his weary voice answered. "Evelyn?"

"What happened to Mrs. Lightfoot?" Her voice strained.

His surprise was palpable. "How did you—"

"Answer me!"

"Sudden deterioration. She's in ICU now." His tone turned grave. "They issued a critical condition notice. I'm at the hospital."

Her breathing quickened. "But she only had leg paralysis before."
